DIV1.P: As it was presented, at the priuate House, in the Blacke-Fryers: By His Maiesties Seruants.
LONDON, Imprinted by A. M. for Iohn Waterson, and are to bee solde at the signe of the Crowne in Pauls Church-yard, 1630,

DIV1.HEAD: TO THE RIGHT HONOVRABLE THE LORD WESTON, LORD HIGH TREASVRER OF ENGLAND.
DIV1.P:
I Should doe my inclination wrong, to call this, the first Testimony of my Zeale to your Lordshippe: For I did neuer
thinke the wonder, or the prayse that I haue written, iust; vntill I found your Lordships Chara∣cter in both: and yet the age is growne vnworthy to receiue such truths; therefore, some were purposely conceal'd; and this fit esteeme of your Lordship, is chiefly left to delight Posterity. I could vrge the dignitie of Dram∣matick-Poems, but that were vain∣ly to direct, rather then wooe, an acceptation. Those errors, your Lordshippes leasure shall vouchsafe to reade in this Tra∣gedy, are its originall Crimes, hauing receiu'd no examination since the Birth, and being ad∣uised to correct it, by a suruay, I sayd; I had study'd your Lord∣ship,
and would not lessen, the noble office of your Mercy. This confidence (I hope) shall no∣thing preiudice

CLOSER.SIGNED: Your Lordships hum∣ble Seruant. WILLIAM D'AVENANT.

LIST.HEAD: The Persons of this Tragedy.
LIST.ITEM: COSIMO. A Courtier, and Cousen to Castruchio.
DORIDO. A Gentleman, Companion with both.
BORACHIO. A Rustick, Tennant, and Seruant to Lothario.
CORSA. Sister to Foreste, Wife to Lucio.

DIV2.HEAD: Actus Primus. Scena Prima.

SP.SPEAKER: FOREST.
SP.L: I must not be so rude as to beleeue
That you (my Lord) can your affections set;
Vpon a Mayde, so humble in her birth
As she you name, for regard of honour
Doe not mock the sister of your seruant.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucio.
SP.L: This way to madnesse leads, teach not my heart
Such modern Heraldry. Let it dispose
Of charitable thoughts, with naturall eies,
Vnlimmited by customary forme,
Which gaine, and nicetie haue made an Art,
Virtue, not blood enobles vs, and ernes
Her atribute, without hereditary helpe
From ancestors. O my deere Foreste?
Thy sister with such noble wealth is fraught,
That to be couetous for her, appeares,
A holy sinne. But thou art cruell growne
Thy memory is sick. The old effects
That witnesse how I loue thy learned soule,
Are quite forgot.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: Young Lord, disclaime that thought!
Heare I Promulgate, you my Patron are;
You found me in estate so poore, so lowe,
That you were faine to stoope to lift me vp,
You are the Dukes Creature! who doates by Art,
Who in his loue, and kindnesse, Method keepes:
He holdeth thus his Armes, in fearefull care
Not to bruse you with his deere embracements,
And what is she whose Virgin blood disdaines
To quench your lawfull fire? or whom the Duk
Would not procure to climbe your Marriage be
Vpon her Knees? And shall I then
(Like to the treacherous Moone) striue to eclip
The Sunne that giues me light? Shall I consent
That she, that tumbled in a Wombe with me,
Shall giue your Issue birth? The royall Duke
Would thanke me for such charitie. My Lord
Though you are wise, you are but young.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucio.
SP.L: Heart of Viper!
Sure Time hath lost his feathers from his Heeles,
Marke how slow he goes? Shall I neere be olde
That my designes may repute haue,
And credit in the World. I doe not aske
Thy Sister for my Whore; but for my Wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: Sir t'is already ioynd vnto my Creede▪
For I would eate your Heart, should it contriue
A way in thought, how to cheate my Sister
Of her pure Chastitie. I loue you so
That I with care suppose; She not deserues
To be your Wife, and so esteeme of her
That she is much too good, to be your Whore.
In this new Argument, I am too bolde,
You know my duty well. The Dukes abroad
Though but the birth of day. Goe Sir!

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Duke, Castruchio, Dorido, Cosimo, Page: and Followers.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: My glorious Boy, you are too vigilant:
The Sunne, and you, doe visite me at once.
This courtship is not safe. You must not meete
Your Louer, with a Riuall, glorious
As your selfe. Foreste! welcome from Genoa,
How fares our Brother Cardinall?

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: In health, and ease. He badde me tell your Grace
It was a deed of charitie to thinke
Him worthy of this same great imployment.
And this letter he humbly recommends
To your perusall.

DIV2.STAGE: Duke reads the Let∣ter to himselfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: How can it choose
But choke the very Soule, and bruse the Heart
To thinke that such a giddy Snipe: a Foole
(That meerely liues to disparage Nature)
Should creepe to this ambitious gouernment.
Still he rules the Ruler. The Duke is Ward
Vnto a Page; whose Eie-browes weare more Beard,
Then doth his Chinne: And there's his Instrument,
A darke fellow; that with dsguised Lookes
Coud cheat an Hypocrite, older then Time.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorid.
SP.L: I'ue heard a better Character of both,
Such, as to the young Count, Witt, and vallour giues:
Vnto Foreste, honest Spirits.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: Rport is then become a Bawde to Luck;
Whom Fortune do henrich, Fame doth flatter.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Sure this tame Priest will make vs all Cowards.
We must a truce confirme with Genoa.
Well, be it so. Where now (my noble Boy)
Shall I occasion finde, to testifie
That you deserue my loue, by vertue of your owne?
In sickely times, when Warre and ciuill Spleene
Besiege the Heart, with treacherous designes,
A friend shall find a cause to make him knowne,
But now in faire weather: I neede not aske
What Houell's nere?

SP.SPEAKER: Lucio.
SP.L: In this, I dare discredite Fate.
They are not so wealthy in affliction:
With sorrow so well stor'd; as could suffice
To trie my sufferance: in the behalfe
Of you my Prince, and still royall Master.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Dar'st thou then die for me?
Heere—make thy selfe a sacrifice to Fame,
Take it: and I will be thy Chronicler.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucio.
SP.L: It were (Sir) but ingratitude in me
To lssen thus, the number sanctifide
Of your true friends. Be you pleas'd to sheath it,
In that same part, which you doe most abhorre.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: O Lucio! thou art my Earewg now,
Creep'st in my eare, to feast vpon my Braines.
When in my priuate graue I lye inclos'd,
More silent then my ruin'd Fame: no tongue
Shall pay his tribute to my memory
But thine: for thou art likely to suruiue.
Thy yeares are few, but full of gratitude.—
Come: hye we to the Parke: The sprightfull morne
Giues motion wings, and libertie to those
Whom lamenesse stakes vnto the ground.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: Royall dotard, like tinder, thou dost waste
Thy forced fire: to giue another light
Whose sawcy flame will darken thine. Monstrous!

SP.SPEAKER: Dorid.
SP.L: Why dost thou spend thy gall in secret thus?
A pox vpon't: turne thoughts to action:
Heauen knowes, I had rather enrich my selfe,
Then enuy others wealth. Imploy thy brayne.
Get the Dukes fist to this; and thou shalt share
Fiue hundred Crownes.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: What is't?

SP.SPEAKER: Dorid.
SP.L: The old businesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: And not yet sign'd: This t'is to be modest.
Had I had reputation in thy Creede
It had beene done long since. There's my agent.
Hence and prouide me thanks. Saue you Signior.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: You may with charitie.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: Am I in your remembrance sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: Signior Castruchio, as I take you.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: The same. Because I neuer did desire
To gaine by being troublesome, I lost
The deere benifit of the practique part.
Custom's a sutors safe encourager.
I the Duke haue seru'd, since I was able
To serue my selfe. Yet neuer had the luck
To get by it: and as the times promise,
Neuer shall: Vnlesse I imitate the Crab,
And find my way (as he doth his) backwards.
That is. to make petition to the foote
That he will please t'instruct, and teach the head
When to comiserate my affaire.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: Signior. I neede a comment to your words.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: If you will mooue my Lord (the Count)
To get the Dukes faire hand, subscribed heere;
Then shall I feele my selfe well vnderstood.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: Sir my abillities are most pregnant
When I find I may be profitable
To any Courtiers iust, and modest sute.
I pray what sense carries the inscription?

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: Only this Sir. There is an Engine made
Which spends its strength by force of nimble wheeles,
For they once screwed vp, in their returne
Will riue on Oake: but with such subtill force
That motion giues no leasure to impediment.
The large and ponderous Logge is soone consum'd,
To shauings more transparant then a Glasse.
Of these the skillull Boxes make, Scabbards,
Sheathes, Cheasts, and molds for childrens Cabinets.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: Trust me an Engine of importance great.
But now, what would the Enginere himselfe?

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: Faith Signior, nought but a Monopoly
For all those wares, his Engine makes.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: Keepe it. Good sir keepe it. A monopoly
Why sir the common-wealth hath beene so crush'd,
With th'insulting Charter of such Parents,
That now the very word defiles the cause.
I had thought you Signior would haue ingag'd
My industry in such a sute as might
Noway disparedg though it did enrich;
How euer not abuse the publique weale.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: Very good Sir. My Lord the Count, your selfe
(His seruile Instrument) and some others,
Of this new faction that now, engrosse
All Offices, and send your Scoutes abroad
Intelligencers strict, that bring you home
The number, and the rate of what your selues,
Or others in the darke can put to sale.
Nature hath not altered yet: the first
And antick method to preserue our breaths.
We must eate bread if we intend to liue;
Which how to get (vnlesse this humble way
That you deride) In troth I cannot tell.
It makes me mad to thinke you should expose
Vs Men of Heart, to those fastidious helpes
That scape your owne acceptance. Your wide Threats,
That soone will swallow any thing which fills
Although it nourish not. A pox vpon you all!

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: I did expect you would begin to rayle.
Good troubled Soule! I knew you well before.
You are the only Man, whose wealthy Muse
Doth furnish all the Fidlers in the State
With dsp'rate Ballads, and inuectiue Songs.
Libells of such weake facy and composure
That we doe all esteeme it greater wrong
T'haue our Names extant in such paltery Ryme
Then in the slanderous sence.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: Very well Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: You, you must be a Satyrist forsooth,
Calumniate by instinct and inspiration.
As if iust Heauen would borrow Gall of you,
Wherewith to write our faults. (O strict account!)
Your Gall, which in the Pen so ouerflowes,
That still it blots, where in inscribs.
You imitate the propertie of Doggs,
Who barke and snarle most at him they know not
For else among all those you scandalize
Why nam'd you me? (almost a stranger to your Eye)
My Ancestors that built no Monument
For their fames to dwell in; You also bring
Into the knowledge of the criticke World.
Why I could neuer see thee yet but druke:
Which makes thy Verses reele and stagger so.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: Come sir! We may exchange one thrust vnseene.
They draw fight, close, For stings down Cas & disarmes him.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: A prety Curr! dare it bite as well as barke!
How now sir, your Mathematicall thrusts!
Then haue at ye—Yeeld me thy Sword, or else thou dy'st.
I haue no ioy to set a liberty
A Soule so vnprepar'd. And as thou art
My Enemy, I take a full reuenge,
By suffering thy corrupted blood to dwell.
And taint within th vaines. W'are discouered—
Take thy sword Now get thee home and rayle vpon't,
Because t'would fight no better.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: Yet we may meete i'th' darke. You haue a throat
And there are Kniues in Italy.

SP.SPEAKER: Forest.
SP.L: A good day attend my ghostly Father!
Doth this your tariance heere discouer ought,
You would with me?

SP.SPEAKER: Monke.
SP.L: Your leasure shall produce my vtterance.
O Sonne, your fame is of complexion cleere,
Such as ensnares the virtuous Eye, to loue
And adoration. Such as would procure
All the skilfull Angels sutors to her,
And such as serues for my encouragement
For I no letters haue from Noble friends,
Which a requitall from themselues inuite,
By Courtship bold, and troublesome to others,
Noram I with that wicked mettall stor'd,
That rules the mighty, and betrayes the minde
To toyle in a designe, which angers Heauen,
And makes the Deuill blush. But yet (deere Sonne)
I haue a suite to thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: Which I desire to know.

SP.SPEAKER: Monke,
SP.L: In the ancient Covent of S. Austine
There is a holy brother lately dead,
Whose place if you will but confirme on me
By the Dukes letter to the brother-hood,
Then shall I better leasure haue to pray
For you my Patron.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: Alas my Father!
The times are more obseruant to your Tribe.
It is the method now that your deserts
Need not to vsher but succeed reward.
The Treatise (written lately) to confute,
The desperate sect in Mantua, calls it you
The Author?

SP.SPEAKER: Monks.
SP.L: It knowes no other.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: There your preferment safely taketh roote.
Beleeue me (ghostly Father) I will choose
The fittest time to woke in your behalfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Monke.
SP.L: Heauen prosper your designes.

SP.SPEAKER: Forest.
SP.L: What throngs of great impediments besiege
The vertuous minde? so thick in multitude,
They iostle one another as they come.
Hath Vice a charter got, that none must rise
But such, who of the Deuils faction are?
The way to honour is not euermore
The way to Hell: a vertuous Man may climbe.
Let the flatterer sell his Lies, else where
It is vnthrifty merchandize to change
My gold for breath. Of all Antagonists
Most charitie I finde in enuious men.
For they doe sooner hurt themselues, then hurt
Or me, or him, that rays'd me vp.
An enuious man is made of thoughts.
To ruminate much doth melt the braine,
And make the heart grow leane. Such men as these:
That in opposing waste their proper strengths:
That sacrifice themselues in silly hope,
To butcher vs; saue Reuenge a labour,
And dye to make experiment of Wrath.
Let Fame discourse aloud vntill she want
An Antidote: I am not scar'd with noyse.
Heere I dismisse my feares. If I can swell
(Vnpoyson'd by those helpes, which Heauen forbids)
Fond loue of ease, shall neere my soule dehort:
Maugre all flattery, enuy, or report.

DIV2.L: O good your Grace heare vs, heare the complaints
Of vs poore Men: O heare vs! we are all
Vndone! Good your Honour heare vs.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Death encounter 'em! Lucio shut the doore!
Tis the plague of greatnesse, the curse
Of pompe, that in our darkest priuacie, wee must
Euen publique be to euery Mans affaires.
How now! All these sawcy Troopes of brawling
Sutors, attend on you my glorious Boy.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucio
SP.L: It is their humble skill not to arriue
Before your Grace, but by an Aduocate
A Mediatour blessed in your Eies.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke
SP.L: How apt am I to loue! yet now obserue
Vnkindnesse in my care, and bitternesse
In Physicke. I study how to make thee lesse
That I may make thee more and more my owne.
Office and Dignity are Enemies
To health, and ease. Respect growes tedious
Obseruance troublesome, where ti's most due.
He that giues his Soule no more imployment
Then what's her owne: may sleepe within a Drumme.
While busie Hearts, that loue to vndertake
Beyond their reach of yeeres: are faine to vse
Drowsie potions: yet watch the Winter night
With more distinction then the Parish Clocke.
Could'st thou resigne thy titles and thy cares
To make me yet more capable of still
Enioying thee?

SP.SPEAKER: Lucio.
SP.L: My zeale vnto my selfe forbids my speech.
Since if I make reply to this, I but
Disparedge duty, and consume my breath.
Where ight is young, and cleere, there Spectacles
Are troublesome; and rather hide, then shew
The obiect. The most deuout obedience
Which I shall euer owe vnto your Grace
Becomes my heart, much better then my tongue.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: But yet obserue (my Lucio)
Th'vnkind tricks of Nature: how we are fool'd
By a religious constancy in Loue.
A Princes hate doth ruine where it falls:
But his affection warmeth where it shines
Vntill it kindle fire to scorch himselfe.
If we are subiect to the sinne of Heauen,
(Too much charitie) extreamity of loue:
Let there be mercy shewen in punishment.
Why is the corrupted vse of Royall loue
Imputed to our charge, to our Audit layd?
We that with all those Organs furnish'd are
All those faculties naturall in Men:
Yet limitted in vse of each: prescrib'd
Our conuersation, by a sawcy forme
Of State. How can we choose (by this restraint)
But struggle more for liberty? make choise
Of some one Eare; wherein to empty out our Soules,
When they are full of busie thoughts; of plotts
Abortiue, crude, and thinne. T'is cheape, and base
For Maiestie not to be singular
In all effects. O then, if I must giue my heart
To the command of one: send him (sweete Heauen!)
A modest appetite: teach him to know
The stomacke sooner surfeits with too much,
Then starues for lacke of that supply
Which couetous Ambition calleth want.
For when my Friend beggs, my bounty then
Concludes to make me poore before that he
Shall so vnthrifty be of breath to aske in vaine.
Distraction! tamenesse! O my Lucio.
How canst thou conster this. After I haue chid
I seeme to flatter thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucio.
SP.L: My gracious Lord!—

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Peace—
I will no more imploy my memory
Thus to discourage thine. Where's Foreste!
T'is fit he know you are not vigilant
In his behalfe. Farelo de Sforza
(My old Secretary) is newly dead:
The place is his. I shall expect no thankes
From you, nor yet from him:
My bounty is requited in her choice.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucio.
SP.L: Your Grace will bring vs both within the reach
Of publique enuy.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Thou now would'st certifie,
His birth obscure and base discourageth
Such earnest helpe to his so great promotion.
Not a iot: Know my Boy! t'is the vulgar,
Not the Royall trade to patch vp things:
Or seeke to mend what was before of qualitie
Perfect enough it selfe. To make a Man
Of nothing: why this same creation
Enclines a little neere Diuinitie.
Neere the old performance; which from Chaos
Drew this multitude of subtill formes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucio.
SP.L: Since you (the royall maker) doe commend
The mettall, and your workemanshippe; it shewes
There's little skill in those which enuy him.
Foreste is your Creature. Many times
I doe acquaint him what the generall voyce
Doth vrge in his disgrace. He laughs it out
And sweares he would not loose that priuiledge
Which Nature gaue him by her kinde mistake
In his natiuitie, for the Seas worth.
As if from's Issue, he could ne're deserue.
A nument, vlesse himselfe doe hewe
The stones whereof t'is built: vnlesse he raise
His Monument on a Wart; his dignitie
On pouertie obscure and base.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: We doe affct his thoughts Such industry
Proclaimes him fit for high designes: Some Men
Attend the talking Drumme, and riddle out
Their liues on Earth; with Madnesse Sophistry:
Calling their losse, their gaine, danger, delight.
Some men conuerse with Bookes, and melt the braine
In sulln study how to vindicate
The liberall Arts. Those loose formalitie,
Then grow Methodicall; and dy i'th' darke.
Some practise rules of State, and suffer much
For Honors sake: nay tread vpon themselues
At first; to reach the higher. Some pursue
The Plough; and in their wholesome sweat doe swimme.
And some that furnish'd are with nimbler soules,
Imploy their times in wanton exercise;
Masques and Reuells: the complements of Loue,
And Loue I finde the easiest vanity.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucio.
SP.L: O gentle Corsa! make it so with me,
Faine would I (if I durst) reueale to him
The heate of my affection, and where t'is fix'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Hearke: sure the gallery doore is left vnlockt.
Are we debard all place of priuacie?
Nature in vs hath lost her vulgar right.
A loude, bawling sutor; doth not waken
Charitie, but deafen her.
A shame vpon 'em all? In Lucio.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Sutors at the other doore.
DIV2.L: 1. Heauen blesse his Grace!
2. Amen: and my Lord the Count's good Honor.
3. Friend▪ went the Duke this way?
2. Heere. This way.
3. Pray shew me him: they call Signior Lucio
2. The Count. Come, I'le shew you him.
1. Follow, follow, follow.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor
SP.L: Dost heere? Cosimo.

SP.SPEAKER: Cosi.
SP.L: What sayst thou?

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: I prethee stay, why slip but heere asid
And thou shalt see the most resplendent Fopp,
That euer did discredit Nature. Sigmor.
Lothario; a Countrey Gentleman
But now the Court Baboone: who perswades himselfe,
(Out of a new kinde of madnesse) to be
The Dukes fauorite. He comes. Th'other is
A bundle of Prouerbs: whom he seduc'd
From the Plough; to serue him for Preferment.

SP.SPEAKER: Lotha.
SP.L: Borachio.

SP.SPEAKER: Bor.
SP.L: My Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: Loth.
SP.L: Suruay my garments round, and then declare If I haue hit it?

SP.SPEAKER: Bor.
SP.L: You haue sir: but not the marke.

SP.SPEAKER: Loth.
SP.L: What marke? thou bold Parishioner of Hell.

SP.SPEAKER: Bor.
SP.L: Why Sir, the marke I aime at: Preferment.
After a storme, comes a calme: the harder
You blow, the sooner your Cheekes will ake: and he
That cares for your anger, may haue more of't
When he list, for my part, I know my Mother.

SP.SPEAKER: Loth.
SP.L: The froward Sisters haue conspir'd Slaue! Dog
Wilt thou neuer leaue this immense folly?
Can nothing serue these dull Lippes but Prouerbs?

SP.SPEAKER: Bor.
SP.L: Sir, I know none of your Prouerbs. First come,
First seru'd. These words that are neerest the tongue,
Haue opportunitie soonest to leaue
The mouth.

SP.SPEAKER: Loth.
SP.L: Is it then decreed, I must grow mad?

SP.SPEAKER: Bor.
SP.L: I'le be no more flowed, nor brus'd, not I
What need my Lord, be beholding to me
For's mirth; when he may laugh at's owne folly?
Besides though motion and exercise
Be good for grosse bodies; therefore, must they
Of the Guard, pitch me vp and downe like a barre?

SP.SPEAKER: Loth.
SP.L: Sa, sa, sa, A mutinie in Heauen!

SP.SPEAKER: Bor.
SP.L: If there be; You are not likely to come
Thither to appease it, first end this quarrell
Vpon earth, I haue seru'd you this sixe Moneths,
In hope of an Office; and am no more
An Officer then she that bore me.

SP.SPEAKER: Loth.
SP.L: Alas poore foole!
I pitty thee. Thou wilt beleeue nothing
But that which may be seene or vnderstood.
I say thou art an Officer. Or if thou art not
Thou shalt be; which is better: for that same
Which we now enioy is in some danger
To be lost: but that which we neuer had
Cannot be lost before we haue it.

SP.SPEAKER: Bora.
SP.L: O rare conclusion:

SP.SPEAKER: Loth.
SP.L: Besides. Looke heere and then reioyce, Is the Count
(Whom they call my Riuall ith' Dukes fauour)
Is he (I say) accoutred like to me?
Why his sleeues sit like stockins on his Armes.
His Breeches are like two Clokebags, halfe sowde
Together in the Twist: and his other
Garments shew like Playsters on him. Follow.
And make thy fortune fat.

SP.SPEAKER: Bora.
SP.L: Well. He that still expects, but tires his hope,
What One cannot, another can: t'is so
With dayes and houres too. And for my part
Let the Glasse runne out.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorid.
SP.L: His Man's as full of Prouerbs
As a Constable: he coyns 'em himselfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Cos.
SP.L: And such another Heade-peece fill'd with Whay
As is the Master heere, the Sunne nere saw.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorid.
SP.L: He walkes like a Zealand-storke.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: But sure the Duke
Enables error in their fancy, by some
Behauiour equiualent to what
The Master, and the Man expect: for else
Folly cannot be so sickely-Eied; but time
Will giue it strength to know it selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorid.
SP.L: Why sir; this dignifies the Ieast. They scarce
Ere saw the Duke: and are lesse knowne
Vnto the world. His Grace well apprehends,
These voluntary mistakes of Nature,
In preseruation of their intellects,
Are fitter subiects for accidentall mirth,
Then a Comicall continuance. It is
A leuitie too humble in a Prince
To heede such trifles.

SP.SPEAKER: Cos.
SP.L: Nay—Prethee lead the way▪

SP.SPEAKER: FORES.
SP.L: I cannot tell, why thou (my Girle) should'st ioy
In my aduancement thus. Honour, and place
Bring sullen thoughts with them: businesse of such
A ragged qualitie, as takes away
The amorous garbe: those soft wanton touches,
Wherewith the youthfull flatterer betrayes
The weaker side to action: whose effects
More weakenesse brings. I shall no leasure haue
To comfort thee with smiles: when t'is assign'd
That I must venture for a Boy: t'will be
In haste. My businesse will not suffer me
To stay, and make a prologue to the acte,
To kisse, or simper inuitation.

SP.SPEAKER: Luin.
SP.L: It is not fit I apprehend you now,
But I wish that you would know; My duty
Is so well preseru'd from all corruption:
Which either youth: or fowle example might
Produce: that it in plores for fferance,
To certefie the world how strong it is.

SP.SPEAKER: Forest.
SP.L: I was assur'd before. This is the time,
In which I shall oblige posteritie
Or fall (my wench) by flattering error.
Hast thou to my sister counsaile giuen?
Instructions safe! whereby her actions
May warrant her promotion well deseru'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Luin,
SP.L: It was my tongues last imployment.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores
SP.L: I would haue her weare her growing fortunes,
In a handsome fashion: Doe but obserue
The vnpollish'd garbe of Citty dames: of those
Whom athers purse-strings hoyfe vp to honor.
How they doe sucke their Chinnes into their Neckes.
Simper with vnskilfull leuetie: and trip
On their wanton Toes; like Kibeheel'd-Fayries.
The Deuils damme shewes like a vestall Nunne
To them: more powerfull in humilitie.
Instruct my Sister, gentle wife.—

SP.SPEAKER: Lucio
SP.L: I shall be earnest to my vtmost skill.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: My Lord is come, where's my Sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucin.
SP.L: VVith the Horentine: who instructeth her▪ in musicke.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucio.
SP.L: Signior Foreste,
You see my loue is rude, and bolde. am
The vsher to my owne entrance.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: My good Lord, The prouerbe will perswade you:
To be bold, with whas your owne.
Your title's strong, bo to the house, and me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucio.
SP.L: I am in debt for both. wilt thou not childe.
To see my heart assume this libertie.
Vpon my Tongue: before it rightly knowes!
Thy sisters heart:
The Duke consent, as yet vnasked too: harke?

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: Cease that noyse, tis troublesome:

SP.SPEAKER: Lucio.
SP.L: How Forest? Hast thou eares? and wilt thou
such hopefull harmony,
Thy thrist vnnaturall, wilt thou forbid
Thy friend to share in what is good, sweet tongue
And hand, persist in what your kindnesse profferd.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: Obey him, if the musick not deserue
Your strict attention: You must blame your selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucio.
SP.L: Shew me the way Foreste.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: Whither sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Lucio.
SP.L: My heart is stolne out of my eare; let me
But know the thiefe, and Ile forgiue the robbery.
Speake; who ist that, with a voyce so amorous
And shrill, confounds the others hollow organ?
Still so reseru'd, and vnto me.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: Why then looke there, the voyce was hers, goe sir
And take what else you would enforce from my possession.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucio.
SP.L: Is this that child of Orpheus? how? kneele to me?

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: Stay Sir—If she consent but to abuse
The propertie of motion in such kinde
As may exalt her person but on such
Aboue this height: I am her enemy
For euermore. Consider what you doe.
She brings no portion but humilitie,
If her first payment faile: who dares assure
The future debt? Pray looke into her lappe:
You'le finde she comes not from the East enrich'd
With Diamonds, bright wealth: whose wanton worth
Vnskilfull fancy prises not from vse
But from the idolatrous doting of the eie.
Her chaste obedience is all her dowrie.
O bitter speech! it cuts my very soule
To thinke that fortune should create vs two
Meere patterns of your charitie.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucio.
SP.L: Dare you authorize this Idolatry?
Then I'le kneele too.

SP.SPEAKER: Forest.
SP.L: And I,
Will ioyne to make th'offence seeme virtuous.
Now enterchange your soules. Where passion is
So fond, it cannot well be counterfeit.
Each vnbusied Angel, heare me speake!
O send, send downe vnto this youthfull paire
Celestiall heate. Such serious loue as makes
A businesse of delight; Instruct her soule
To practise duty in the humble straine.
And furnish him with an acceptance prompt.
Make her fruitfull as the Vine; which growes
Crooked with the weight of its owne encrease.
So blessed in their Issue, that when time
Shall thinke them fit to taste the priuiledge
Of Death: they shall not need a Monument
Yet dwell as chiefe i'th' memory of Fame.

SP.SPEAKER: Corsa.
SP.L: Amen, Amen.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucio.
SP.L: Such is my prayer too. O Foreste!
Excessiue ioy disturbs my vtterance.
My words are parted on any tongue. O speake!
Thou know'st my heart! Tell her, there may lie hope,
I shall deserue those Teares that shew like deaw
Vpon the Morning cheeke. Intreat her, that
My yeeres may not disgrace my loue. Though I
Am young, I cannot counterfeit,
I euer speake my thoughts. I am o'recome.

SP.SPEAKER: Corsa.
SP.L: Alas sir, so am I, There needs no Art,
To helpe beliefe, where no suspition is.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: Now; I'le leaue you to your selues.

SP.SPEAKER: Corsa.
SP.L: I'ue much to promise in my owne behalfe:
Of my future loue, and humble duty
To you my deerest Lord. Time layes his hand
On Pyramides of Brasse, and ruines quite
What all the fond Artificers did thinke
Immortall workemanship. He sends his wormes
To Bookes, to old Records: and they deuoure
Th inscription. He loues Ingratitude,
For he destrod the memory of Man:
But I shall neere forget on what strange termes
You ta me to your bed.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucio.
SP.L: Excellent wretch! I am vndone with ioy
I will not blame the Coward to feare death,
Since the world containes such ioy as this.
Why doe you weepe Lady? can you suppose
Foreste would consent to what is done,
Vnlesse he knew there were no danger in't?
Sure his Mother was a Sibyll; he sees
With a prophetique aime; the end of his
Designes; before they come to action.
He is too wise to erre. Why weepe you then?

SP.SPEAKER: Corsa.
SP.L: It is a folly in my Eies.
I know not why they weepe: vnlesse they weepe
Because they now haue lost their libertie;
Heeretofore each man, which chance presented,
Was to them a lawfull obiect: but now,
They are to looke on none but you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucio.
SP.L: Marke then the bondage I impose on mine,
My poore eies haue no obiect, but your face:
Of which I will depriue them thus—
SP.STAGE: Couers her face with her white Vaile.
SP.L: Shroude thee in thy vestall ornaments.
Creepe, creepe, my glorious Sunne, behind a cloud.
For els my eies, will sufeit with delight.
I neuer felt true ioy till now. Me thinks
A briske alacritie, a nimble fire,
Conayes me strangely from my flesh.
Not the Cannons, Iron-entraile, when wrapp'd
Within a swarthy case of troubled Aire,
Could quall me in emphasis of Motion.

SP.SPEAKER: Corsa.
SP.L: Though Moest would suffer me to boast,
Yet t'were not in the power of breath, to make
My ioy so knowne, as i is felt.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucio.
SP.L: Come then (my deare Corsa) the Priest attends
Within; the world wants Men; and Hymen is
A nimble God. When all is past preuention
The Duke shall know my choice.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorid.
SP.L: This disgrace, makes thy Cousen boyle his heart
In his owne blood.

SP.SPEAKER: Cos.
SP.L: He hath writ a most pestilent Libell
Which must be sung all about the city,
By one he calls his Daw; A tall, bigg, fellow.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: I know him. He sings like Phalaris Bull.

SP.SPEAKER: Cos.
SP.L: I supposd at first, he would haue sent him
A Challenge.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: But that's contingent now: Foreste
Being made Secretary of State.

SP.SPEAKER: Cos.
SP.L: I'haue heard o'th' new edict, which institutes
A misterious toy, 'th' Htband, for those
Of the faction.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: Why about two dayes since: one of the sect
Sent me a Challenge. Because my sister
Drunke his Lords health, with her Quoife on. Each houre
These giddy Participles doe imbarque
Themselues for Duels. The one is a kinne
To my honorable Lady. Ih'other
To my very good Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Cos.
SP.L: There comes my Cousen, chawing his leane heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: Good morrow to the Court Satyrist.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: The world is altred Dorido, Foreste
Is stepp'd beyond my reach: we cannot meete
In Duell: The Heralds stand betweene.
But my sine Thrush, can sing you a new Lybell.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: We shall haue your Thrush, in a Cage shortly.
Remember, who you deale withall.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast,
SP.L: Hang him, dll, open slaue, His thoughts may be
Discernd, through the shauing of a deale bod.
I'le sift and winnow him, in an old hat.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: Prethee (sweete Castruchio) leaue thy barkeing.
'Twill bet treason shortly for any man,
To carry eares, within three, miles of thy Tongue.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: Why Signior, what Faction are you of:

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: Not of your faction (Sir) if none returne
Vnto the prison for your libelling.
You remember your Vices-strip'd, and whip'd.
Your trimme Eclogues, the fulsome Satyr too,
Written to his Grace. Wherein you flatter,
Whine, and damne your selfe to get a pardon
For what seemes there a resolute offence.
Satyrs, are more vsefull, now then euer.
Nor grieues it me to see the humour vs'd,
But thus abus'd. To see a Bard still reach
At ho Bayes, Passion o'me! I'le tell thee.
Thy Rmes iclude not so much Braines, as would
Suffice to fill a Cherry-stone.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: Yo'ld faine make me angry.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: I, with thy selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Cos.
SP.L: And then thou spend'st thy Gall, with more iustice,
Then when, thou rayl'st against Foreste.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: Cry you mercy (precious Cox) Hath Foreste,
So great a share in your tongue too? Sympathy
Is corupted. Behold society
Amongst the wicked: whilst a vertuous man,
Is left alone to resist his bad fate.
Let him chide the fulsome Age, raile against
The Times, aloude; though in a Vault: or'tweene
Two Hills. He shall find no zealous ecchoe,
To second his bold Language. When I dye,
I dye a Martyr to the Common-weale.

SP.SPEAKER: Loth.
SP.L: Dull Caytife, leaue these abortiue Prouects,
And talke in the newest fashion. I'le haue
My very Dugge barke i'th' Courtly garbe.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: Steppe aside. They are as mad as thy Cousen.

SP.SPEAKER: Loth.
SP.L: The excrements and meere defects of nature,
shall be reduc'd to Ornaments in me.
I'le feed vpon the tongues of Nightingales,
For so each fart I let, will be a Song—

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: For the Peripateticks being Butchers
Heere in Sienna:—

SP.SPEAKER: Loth.
SP.L: A Pallas hewne in an intire Carbuncle.
Encircled with a More that flowes with Lhasis—

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: Derin'd their Angury from the warme Entrailes
Of a Calfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Bor.
SP.L: Sir. These are some of those, that laugh'd at yee
In the presence.

SP.SPEAKER: Loth.
SP.L: At me? thou lyest. They laugh'd at thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Bora.
SP.L: Why then the Deuill, will ne're giue a Ma
Leasure, to beleeue a trueth.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: Seignior Lothario, the great Minion
To our Duke: I greet your health, with all ioy.

SP.SPEAKER: Cos.
SP.L: And I with all humility.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorid.
SP.L: And I with all celerity.

SP.SPEAKER: Loth.
SP.L: Hearke! thou dull Sinner. Is this reall? hah?

SP.SPEAKER: Bora.
SP.L: Sir, let him, that hath a heart of his owne
Thinke what he list.

SP.SPEAKER: Loth.
SP.L: Doe they adore, or floute me now?

SP.SPEAKER: Bora.
SP.L: All is witccraft. know when the Moone winks
There's something in', besides an ecclips.

SP.SPEAKER: Loth.
SP.L: Miscreant: What suspitious follys
Dost thou creat within that Wolden-skull?
And with what Heathen-phrase vtter'd? Know Dogg,
If I imploy my wrath—

SP.SPEAKER: Bora.
SP.L: Allas sir l'ue more faults then misbeliefe.
Therefore giue me your blesing, and let me
Goe home in peace. T'is true, whn the skie falls
We shall haue Larkes. But let weaker stomachs,
Exect such curious meate. I can eate
Oates, and Garlick, vnder my owne Roofe.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorid.
SP.L: How? will Borachio leaue the Court?

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: What accident of dire portent is fallne?

SP.SPEAKER: Loth.
SP.L: Gntlemen applaude my patience: Because,
He cannot furnish me with wholesome Sutes,
He doubts my power to get 'em granted.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: Why we, will furnish him with Sutes.

SP.SPEAKER: Bora.
SP.L: But wont yee floute, and play the knaue with one?

SP.SPEAKER: Cast
SP.L: How (Knaue!) was that the word?

SP.SPEAKER: Bora.
SP.L: Interpret the word, as your selfe shall please.
I scorne to be your Dictionary.
Marry come vp: Are your eares so tender?
I hope I'm a Man, although a sinner.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: Vse no choller Amorous childe. But if
Thou wantest sutes, thy Lord being neere the Duke,
May furnish thee with—

SP.SPEAKER: Cos.
SP.L: Or me thinks thou would'st become a knighthood
Get him to begg it for thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Bora.
SP.L: No, no, Hot words make but warme aire, A figg
For a Knight-errant; that hath a stile, and nere a hedge.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorid.
SP.L: Then get a Patent to suruay Brine-pits.
Or else for casting Ordinance in Lome.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: Or else search Saint Peters patrimony,
Lay Prebendrys are good, and Symony
Is an old Paradox.

SP.SPEAKER: Bora.
SP.L: Holde, holde
Enough sufficeth all women but whores.
He that expects the Morning lengthens the Night
Therefore straitway let my Lord get the Duke
To signe these Patents: which done
I'le returne to the wife of my bowels,
And dye for ioy.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: Why this, is fit, and requisite.

SP.SPEAKER: Cos.
SP.L: If Signior Lothario doe consent.

SP.SPEAKER: Loth.
SP.L: It is decreed.

SP.SPEAKER: Bora.
SP.L: Who would hasten Time, when we may be old
Too soone. Let me take downe a Cushion, and pray.
For I shall haue more dignitie then will suffice
To damne a Monke.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: Who could perish in a better cause?

SP.SPEAKER: Bora.
SP.L: Why, can I helpe it? If a man be borne
To Offices. Or as my Master sayd,
Predestinate in the wombe of greatnesse.
Tis not our faults. Each man obayes his Starre,
In spight of his Teeth,

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: All this is Alcaron.

SP.SPEAKER: Bora.
SP.L: One thing grieues me. I'ue a badd memory
Already, and now t'will be made worse.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: How can preferment hurt thy memory?

SP.SPEAKER: Bora.
SP.L: O Sir! preferment makes a man forget
His deerest friends; nay his kindred too.

SP.SPEAKER: Cos.
SP.L: Looke, Thy Master's building more Castles, in the Aire.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: He has intelligence from Spaine, and fortefies,
To no purpose gainst the next Spring.

SP.SPEAKER: Loth.
SP.L: All offices shall be sold i'th' darke—

SP.SPEAKER: Bora.
SP.L: How! Grow not old in anothers garment,
Sell what's your owne, Some of those offices
Are mine by promise.

SP.SPEAKER: Loth.
SP.L: Still, crosse to my designes. Ile stretch your Sinws

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: Hold! Signior Lothario, hold! Mercy
Becomes the powerfull,

SP.SPEAKER: Bora.
SP.L: Let the Deuill take the Knighthood, and make
His Damme a Lady. I'le not be his Asse,
SP.STAGE: Exit Bor. Loth. running after him.
SP.L: That seru'd for blowes, and Prouander.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: Lets relieue Borachio, or all our Comick Scenes
Are at an end.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Foreste

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: My gracious Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Are yet our Letters to his Holinesse
Dispatch'd?

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: They are so please your Grace.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Did the French-Embassador make some shew
Of discontent at his departure hence?

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: Both in his words and lookes: for when he heard
Th' English-Leiger had oppos'd his Treaty
Concerning trassique with the Florentine,
His anger straight dismissed the Argument,
And seiz'd vpon the Nation, nay rayl'd
Against the Leiger too, whose opposition,
Might be chidden as too nice a Virtue,
But could not be accused as a vice,
Tis knowne indeed the French doe take a prides,
In the emphasis of sudden anger,
As if alacritie in ill did make,
The fault looke handsomely, and dulnesse adde
Deformitie to sinne.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Tis faithfully obseru'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: Swell'd with vncharitable pride: such as
Admits no stile of Neighbour; as if growne
Aboue the vse of friendshippe. They seeme to call
Those mighty Ilanders neerest their soyle,
Poore borderers to their Continent. Such,
Whose thinne numbers, haue in bloudy battaile,
Made their multitudes their impediments,
Worne their Ensignes, instead of gaudy Skarfes.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: The chance of war,
Admitteth many times of Miracles,
Euen such, as doe discredit History,
High-prouidence confers the conquest there,
Where probability conferd the losse.
And this is done, that we may attribute
The prayse to him that gaue the victory,
Not to them that got it. Obserue besides,
That when the weake doe ouercome: the strong,
Doe leaue that staine, for their Posteritie
To wipe away: which is already done;
The French, haue fiery nible spirits.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: Your Grace deales iustly in your praise. They (haue
Spirits: but they all are vselesse made,
By forward and affectate violence.
He that spends his fury, and his strength
I'th' first charge, must not hope to make's retreate,
So nobly, as the modest Combarant,
Whose onset slowly mooues: as carefull not
T'outride his skill. Their vallour is t'attempt.
Not to performe. T'is a giddy Nation;
And neuer serious but in trifles.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Thou doest mistake in naturall effects,
Where Fanc is so rich, the incident
To sme u-expence. These
Divulge the wealth oh' Braine. uite that is ripe
Is prone to fall, or to selfe.
to the e of archies:
Thy now are full ripe: they reach
The height, and of mortall aeuleies.
Nature them doth stand vpon the verge
Of her yuth The English want
Three udred yeres of that perfection.
And as the Mooe ner'e changes but i'th'full
Euen so the mighty Nations of the Earth,
Change in their greatest glory. First their strict
And rugged dscipline, to vaine delights.
Their solemne Marches next to wanton igs.
Their Battailes fierce to Duells spleenatiue,
Or witty quarrels of the Penne.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.L: Heere may my knees take root: whilst I doe grow
A liuing Statue of true obedience,
Or let my royall Master grant his pardon.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Sure we may trust, the iudgement of our eies,
Thou dost not looke as if thou could'st commit
A sinne so horrid, so vgly as can fright
Our mercy from vs. Rise, we pardon thee.
Now let vs know thy crime.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucio.
SP.L: It is no crime
Vnlesse against that great prerogatiue
Youre eare hath ouerrune. Perhaps my Heart,
Hath made escape through these fonde Eies. And I
(I'th' rash discretion of my youthfull blood)
Confin'd my selfe in Matrimoniall bonds.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Hah! maried? speake suddenly, to whom?

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: Io my Sister. Sir pardon the permission,
Or frowne, and leaue your creature more obscure
Then when you own'd him first. Now is the time
To shew your charity Diuine. Preserue
What you haue made.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Foreste this is ill.
What confederate with vngouern'd youth?
But , we pardon you. Where's the Lady?
Rare beauty!—
You haue our pardon, and our fauour too.
I thus inuite more knowledge of your worth.
Beleeue me Lady: you haue a feature
That ould btray a more experienc'd Eie
Then Lucio's is. Excellent wretch! with a
Timerous modesty, she stifleth vp
Her vterance. O such a pregnant Eye!
And yet slow of speech; is a wonder
More dightfull, then any Nature makes.
Hast thou Lucio, so much vnhppy witt,
As to be ealous yet? with thou suppose
Thy selfe scre in our discouse?

SP.SPEAKER: Lucio.
SP.L: Heauen orbd, your Grace should er'e imploy
Your as to discourse with her
'Till grew .

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Come hither Lady, come, confesse, how chance
Yu haue bwitch'd my Boy with subtill smiles,
With wanon hauiour of those pretty Eies?
Doth Huen bestow such Noble ornaments,
To be abused in the vse: and now
He is your Prisoner too, in cheerefull bonds,
How can you haue the heart to make sch spoile,
And hauock of his beauty? hah! speake Lady!

SP.SPEAKER: Corsa.
SP.L: I hope your Grace hath thoughts more mecifull.
I know this match was made in Heauen; and not
Prouok'd by any sinfull art in me.
How I haue v'd him in this little time
That he hath bin my Lord: let him declare.
My duty is so strict, I need not blush
To heare the story told.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: No! looke, looke there. His Eies for very shame
Their luster's lost are crep't into his head:
Encircled with the weakely cullor blew.
The Roses in his Cheekes are withered quite
His cleere and briske aspect is muddy now
And dull: His voyce (that was so shrill; and could
Euen Trumpet-like, outscolde the Ecchoe)
Is hollow growne, and horce. Haue you then vs'd him well?

SP.SPEAKER: Corsa.
SP.L: Alas (most gracious sir) goe not about
To make my Lord suspect my Loyalty.
If Nature sickne in his faculties;
Which (heauen be thanked) I perceiued not yet,
It cannot prooue a guiltinesse in me.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Beleeu't (young wife) I am no Proselyte,
I still auerr, you are that greedy Nimph,
That hath deuour'd the rich complexion of my Boy.
See how his feature's shrunke? his beauty stain'd?
The Scythian Dame (whose cruelty is such,
Whose lust so prodigall, that she doth striue
To kill the able Lecher in the act;
Making her wombe his Sepulchre) would yet
Haue spard that wanton handsomenesse; to shew
As patterne of her Lenitie.

SP.SPEAKER: Corsa.
SP.L: I hope, your Grace will pardon Ignorance,
That so ill mannerd is, as not to know
Your meaning.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: No matter Lady.
My accusation shall withdraw it selfe.
Pretty innocence! Lucio, prepare.
Tis our will to make thy Wife a Courtier;
She shall be high in fauour; if she'll leaue
Her modesty; that's out of fashion now:
In Neighbour Courts, the Ladys so preuaile
With masculine behauiour: they grow
In factions able to depose their Husbands
From the charter of their Sex.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: T'is strange that his dislike is fled so soone.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Your Mariage we wil solemnize with masques,
And Reuels. If Inuention uer meane,
To get reward for subtiltie; tis now.
We take notice (Lucio) She is thy wife,
And thy sister our Foreste.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores. Lucio.
SP.L: We your Graces humblest Creatures.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: Affection is become a Parasite;
Striues to please, whom it cannot benifit.

DIV2.HEAD: Actus Tertius. Scena Prima.

SP.SPEAKER: DORIDO,
SP.L: Knowne, by whom by Citty witts!

SP.SPEAKER: Cos.
SP.L: Or my Ladys workemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: Who ne're saw verse, but what their Sutors writ,
Which they read like Prose too.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: I'le not discredit my patience, talke on.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: They say you are particular with a
Great Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Cos.
SP.L: Yes, and her Pensioner.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: Some loose thing (belike) yet will be at charge,
To secure her fame from noyse. For thou prayst
Against all lechery but thine owne.

SP.SPEAKER: Cos.
SP.L: And she hath wish'd in witty-penitence,
Thou had'st beene single in the world,

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: I, for then she had liu'd chaste. He growes angry,
His eies looke red.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: No Sir. They blush to see a Foole.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: T'were fit they would imploy their modesty
At home. For thou art a foole in print.

SP.SPEAKER: Cos.
SP.L: Yet had he liu'd, when the old Sybill,
Presented her diuine Manuscripts, to
The dull Romane; he would haue scolded with her,
Vnlesse his Pamphlets had attain'd the first
Acceptance.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: True, for euery Poet thinks himselfe
The best Poet in the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Cos.
SP.L: And that Satyr not the worst; wherin
He chides Women, for wearing their Halfe-Ruffes,
Which pinn'd behin'd trans sctuates the face,
Or makes'em looke, like Ianus with two faces.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorid.
SP.L: A iust exception: for going hastily
To kisse his whore; he could not find her Mouth.

SP.SPEAKER: Cos.
SP.L: Why sure her breath was strong enough
To direct him to it.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: Yet I haue heard nothing, but what deserues
More pitty, then anger.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorid.
SP.L: Now when he hath prouided some high toy
For the Presse; he thinks on ddiction,
Strait chooseth one of the faction; who must
Not Patronize, but buy what he makes vendable,
With praise in the Epistle.

SP.SPEAKER: Cos.
SP.L: Can you deny this Cousen Satyrist?

SP.SPEAKER: Dorid
SP.L: And nothing makes Learning so cheape; but that
Euery writer sells his works.

SP.SPEAKER: Cos.
SP.L: Nay let's follow; and worry him to peeces.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucio. Foreste.
SP.L: Our ruine is contriu'd aboue.
If our Master pocue vnkin'd, the Planets
Gouerne ill: For our gratitude, and care,
Deserues more constancy.

SP.SPEAKER: Foreste
SP.L: Lookes he so strangely on yee?

SP.SPEAKER: Lucio
SP.L: As if the obiect were but new to him.
And his owne heart vnsetled in his bast.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: Is his violence so soone tir'd? suruay
The Register of your owne deeds. Speake Sir,
Haue you so engross'd his eares, as if their
Organ, were yours, not his. Confin'd 'em to
Your owne tongue: and so dpriu'd the sorrowfull,
The grieu'd in heart, of an easie audience?

SP.SPEAKER: Lucio.
SP.L: euer.

SP.SPEAKER: Forest.
SP.L: Since you haue shar'd the Dukes prerogatiue,
And by his loue, held opposition.
At such great aduantage. did you e're slight
With cheape regard, those of high, and Noble birth?

SP.SPEAKER: Lucio.
SP.L: My soule abhorrs such tyranny.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: Haue those who weare th'Eternalls Liuery
Bought their wages of ye? Or haue they found
Bold, and skilfull flattery, more helps
Aduacement; then deepe and modest Learning?

SP.SPEAKER: Lucio.
SP.L: Neuer, since my distinction was of power,
To helpe its choyce.

SP.SPEAKER: Forest.
SP.L: In nice triall, or euidence of Law,
Hath Custome (which only giues vs hope
Of certainty in Iustice) bin traduc'd
By your obscure helpe?

SP.SPEAKER: Lucio.
SP.L: Neuer.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: Hath the desolate Widow scar'd mercy
From your eies, with her old ruin'd beauty,
(For griefe was neuer amorous) or hath
The torne Begger too soone dismissed your charitie
Because not giddy enough to delight
Wantonesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucio.
SP.L: Neuer.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: Then if our great Master withdraw his loue;
The weight of sufferance cannot bruise ye;
For the whole world will share i'th burden.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter a young Gentleman with a Letter.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucio.
SP.L: From whom is this sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: From my Lord Marquise de Loretta.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucio.
SP.L: I humbly kisse his hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: Now luck flatter me but once, and I am made—
Tis short, pray heauen it be sweete, or I'le nere loue
The Prouerb.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucio.
SP.L: Sir, haue you euer bin in seruice,
Vnder any eminent Commander?

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: Neuer yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucio.
SP.L: Reade these Foreste.
How Reputation lessens in esteme.
Courtesie growes so cheape, that deniall,
Seemes lesse troublesome then consent.
And performance is only Lazy.
The labor of subscription hinders more,
Then thought of that, to which it doth subscribe.
This Letter would faine make you a Captaine
In the new Troupes, sent to the Valtaline.
But sure your modesty will teach you baulke
The graunt, though I should beg ye to receau't.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: Sir. Shall the grey head, the old Souldier.
That tries misfortune by his constancy
In sufferance; ffronts the winters rage;
Whilst his blood is frozen into Corrall,
His sinnes into Wyer: whole Vallor thinkes
To weare Chain'd shot, as bracelets on his Loynes.
Shall his preferment be intercepted?
Shall he now traile a Pike vnder a Boy,
Whose experience is younger then his face?

SP.SPEAKER: Lucio.
SP.L: No, the frienship of the noble Marquisse
Shall neuer countenance vniust deeds.
Finde a Sute more capable of my grant,
And your acceptance, it is your owne.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: Noble Signior, I'le put ye to the test.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: Princes letters are ceper far then those
Which Scriuenrs put to sale. If such Pigmyes,
Apes in doublets, procure command oth' Campe,
Let the Cranes wage war agen. No opposition
Is too weake to ruinate.—Goe young Lord,
The Duke is ill accompany'd, if ony
With his owne thoughts. Discouer more. Perhaps
His discontent concerns not you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucio
SP.L: I feare, yet my hopes would faine comfort me,
Farewell.

SP.SPEAKER: Luin.
SP.L: I would not be vnmannerly, but if
She be at leasure, tell her, I am heere.

SP.SPEAKER: Dua.
SP.L: Please your Ladyship to sit, Il'e tell her so.
She's come already.

SP.SPEAKER: Corsa.
SP.L: I saw your entrance. How doe you Sister?

SP.SPEAKER: Luin.
SP.L: I humbly thanke your honor, I am well,
Pray dismisse your woman: I would impart
A priuacy.

SP.SPEAKER: Corsa.
SP.L: Watch my Lords comming from the Duke, and bring
Me word, before he is vncoach'd

SP.SPEAKER: Dua.
SP.L: I shall.

SP.SPEAKER: Luin.
SP.L: O Madam Time is now growne old, and runnes
But slowly, I thought each Hower, a yeere,
Vntill I saw your Ladyship.

SP.SPEAKER: Cor.
SP.L: Why what's the matter? I hope my brother's well

SP.SPEAKER: Luin.
SP.L: Yes, I thanke heauen. But pray come hither.
Who doe you suppose was with me last night,
When my husband was at Court?

SP.SPEAKER: Corsa
SP.L: How should I tell, without you instruct me.

SP.SPEAKER: Luin.
SP.L: Why giue a guesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Corsa.
SP.L: The Lady Benuolia, or the Lady
Vtruvia, who was it?

SP.SPEAKER: Luin.
SP.L: Nay t'was a Man too.

SP.SPEAKER: Corsa.
SP.L: That's fine i'faith, pray name him to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Luin.
SP.L: What thinke you of the best man in Sienna?

SP.SPEAKER: Corsa.
SP.L: How! was the Duke with ye?

SP.SPEAKER: Luin.
SP.L: Yes, disguis'd too: he either came, (or else
Pretended so) to meete your husband there.
After some talke, (in which he did expresse
His loue to all our family) he gaue
An ample praise of you: and sayd he saw
Already so much worth in your faire breast
As will adde a knot to your Lords Heart,
And his owne: nay and make his constant loue
A patterne for euery royall Master.

SP.SPEAKER: Corsa.
SP.L: Indeed, I dayly pray to haue it so.

SP.SPEAKER: Luin.
SP.L: Then he gaue me this same Iewell; to you
He recommended the receipt of this.

SP.SPEAKER: Corsa
SP.L: Trust me wench, they are both full of glory
Rarely cut, and set.

SP.SPEAKER: Luin.
SP.L: Your's is the better of the twaine,

SP.SPEAKER: Corsa.
SP.L: It is.
But truely I mislike the manner of
The gift. Dost thou thinke his thoughts are honorable?
I prethee tell me?

SP.SPEAKER: Luin.
SP.L: Th'are such as I suspected at the first,
Such as made me to refuse these Iewels.
He swore I was a Traytor, if I thought.
He meant amisse Or if I did deny
To beare this same to you, I did but ill
Require his kind request vnto my husband.
Then in the close he vsd such Art, such subtill phrase,
To free his thoughts from the strict iealousie
Of mine; as reconcil'd me to obey his will.
You know besides how harsh it is to chide
With Maiestie, or slight Princes fauors.

SP.SPEAKER: Corsa.
SP.L: I'le shew to my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Luin.
SP.L: I had thought t'haue shewne my husband mine too
But since t'is capable of curious
Questioning, I meane to stay awhile.

SP.SPEAKER: Corsa.
SP.L: Thou counsayl'st well. Wee'll weare 'em both at once.
Mine is the best, I e're was Mistresse of.

SP.SPEAKER: Luin.
SP.L: And mine is not ecclipsed much by yours.

SP.SPEAKER: Dua.
SP.L: Madam, my Lord is neere at hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Corsa.
SP.L: Come Sister, we shall heere the newes at Court.

SP.SPEAKER: Luin.
SP.L: I'le waite vpon your Ladyship.

DIV2.STAGE: Exeunt omnes. Enter Castruchio, Lothario, Borachio.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: Sir Knight, beleeu't Foreste is the Man▪
That duls your reputation with the Duke.
And subbornes the Count against ye.

SP.SPEAKER: Loth.
SP.L: Dares he controle my purposes?

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: Aske honest Borachio else.

SP.SPEAKER: Bora.
SP.L: Nay He'le not beleeue me: though I should sw
You slout him behind his backe: and when a man
Sees things plainely; he neede not buy spectacles,
Till he grow old.

SP.SPEAKER: Loth.
SP.L: I'le mince the Villaine into sand, to fill
My Howerglasse—

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: In this Garden he walkes continually
After dinner. Heere stay, and expect him.
And Signior in this skin of parchment; marke
What paines I take, to perfect your reuenge.
I'th' shape of tree (which takes roote in Hell)
You shall discouer all his base discent.
On that branch appeares a Hangman. Then,
A Iakes-man, then, a Tynker. On's Mothers side
A Bawde profess'd. then, a Tybb. then a Trypewife.
A Synagogue of Welsh Rabbys; could not
Expresse more skill in Genealogies,
Then this includes. Sir, shew it him, and he
Insaniates strait.

SP.SPEAKER: Loth.
SP.L: I'le make him weare it on his forehead.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: Excellent rage! but not a word of me.
I humbly take my leaue.

SP.SPEAKER: Loth.
SP.L: Not the foure winds (met in March) shall coole my spleene

SP.SPEAKER: Bora.
SP.L: Sir, now we are priuat, tis a fit time
To be troublesome—

SP.SPEAKER: Loth.
SP.L: I'le cram Cerberus, with sopps made of the slaues blood—

SP.SPEAKER: Bora.
SP.L: Concerning those Offices. I'ue thought on'em.
And will haue 'em all in spight of Boltens teeth.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: Signior Lothario! Boracho too.
Thou art an honest fellow.

SP.SPEAKER: Bora.
SP.L: I, your worship is wise, to speake no more,
Then what you may well stand too.

SP.SPEAKER: Loth.
SP.L: Base stemme, deriu'd from I sope roote,
Our Ancestors were not so familliar.
Behold, & grow more mannerly.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: Whats heere? My Pedigree? Some sawcy knaue
Hath counsell'd him, to this affront. What he,
I must know th'originall proiector.
Lay hold vpon those fooles.

SP.SPEAKER: Loth.
SP.L: Lay hold on me?
Take off your hands; or I will tosse ye all
Into the cloudes, and kicke the Mountaines after ye.

SP.SPEAKER: Bora.
SP.L: I pray bid the Gentleman take good heede;
For my Master, can doe all this, and more too
I haue seene him.

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.L: Be you quiet. You that desire Offices.

SP.SPEAKER: Bora.
SP.L: If I doe, what then? there be hose desire
Worse things.

SP.SPEAKER: Loth.
SP.L: Know ye not Rogues, that I can muzle vp
The testifie Vnicorne, in a Spinners threed?

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: Lay all hold on him.

SP.SPEAKER: Bora.
SP.L: He that cannot runne for his Liberty
Hath no courage in his Heeles. Let the Goute
Take him, that hath Leggs, and w'ont vse'em

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: No matter, let him goe. Conuey that foole,
Vnto the Porters Lodge.

SP.SPEAKER: Loth.
SP.L: A Chaos shall succeed this same.

SP.SPEAKER: Foreste.
SP.L: Whither so fast (sweete Lord!)

SP.SPEAKER: Lucio.
SP.L: Foreste, I haue tane my leaue o'th' Duke.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: Must ye away to night.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucio.
SP.L: Now, presently. My followers attend
At doore. I onely came to kisse thy hands.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: The Sunne will faile yee, ere ye reach Lucca.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucio.
SP.L: I must through. His grace will haue it so.
Why dost thou make thy head, to shake and reele,
Vpon thy shoulders thus. Is it o'recome
With thoughts, and such as must be hid from me?

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: Take heede, suspition is the Fauorite
Of Time, and Nature, it takes a sudden grouth:
And gathers in the brest, like Balls of suow,
In snow; vntill the weight make it deny
To be remoou'd: then melts at leasure too.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucio.
SP.L: He's too moderate, that will at my yeeres,
Be satisfied thus.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: Why then consider thus. You goe to Lucca,
There to congratulate the sate aproach
Of the Popes Legate; He hath bin there a weeke;
And why he was not visited ere this
Or why vpon such strict, and short summons.
Your selfe must now be sent; quite puzles me.
Actions rare, and sudden, doe commonly
Proceed from fierce necessitie: or else
From some oblique designe: which is asham'd,
To shew it selfe i'th' publique Rode.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucio.
SP.L: Foreste is this all?

SP.SPEAKER: Forest.
SP.L: Why me sweete Patron: this is enough
Of danger, since none is merited.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucio.
SP.L: Yong thoughts encourage me to sufferance.
Each storme is vsher to a gentle calme:
Why toyles with speede, gets soonest home to rest.
The plodding Mule shall sleepe eternally.
Why should the stricken deare bemane his death:
His obsequies, were full of noble rites:
Acteons Quire, a iolly Requiem gaue:
And th' Arrow from the bow did sing his dirge.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: Thus thy yeeres doe riddle griefe away;
Making sorrow swift, because 'tis mortall.
Let me waite, on your Lordship to your horse,
And at your better leasure read this same.
I'le tell ye as we goe, who brought it me.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: To wrong my boy, vnkinde, incestuous heate!
Why is Copulation legal; it giues
Authoritie to lust, for chastetie
Would soone conclude the World. O virtuous
Predice, when error, preuents folly!
Fiendes, Deuils, that doe liue in liquid fire,
Haue constitutions not halfe so hot,
So riotous as mine. But why this?
The beautious Corsa is not yet defil'd.
He that repents e're he commits a fault,
Doth like a thirsty, sinner store his Soule
With mercy, to absolue that sinne himselfe;
Which he may afterwards, more securely
Fall into. Enough this soone Initiates.
The credulous Count her husband, I haue sent
To Lucca. And tomorrow he returnes.
My plots are limmited too short a time
To become Actions. Nor was it skill
To send the Iewell by her sister. Marke!
My Soule and braine, are perfect Courtiers growne;
In my declention, and my greatest want
They leaue me to instruct, and helpe my selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: These fancies are not old: the whole Court
Obserues him strangely altered. But why
Am I sent for? that I must know, by safe,
And cautelous insinuation.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: How soone, I'ue profited in discipline
Of Hell I must through What I did meane
Adultery at first; will now I feare
Become a Rape.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: Hah! still vpon that string? I like it well,
T'is musicall.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Castrucho! art thou come?
Thou hast bin a Courtier long; but whether
'Twas want of skill in me to choose a Man,
Or want of lucke in thee to be my choyce;
Suspence makes neutrall. But know; my loue
Was tardy, because still voyde of leasure;
To warrant passion well bestowed; by safe
(Though tedious) trials. Affection
That is slow, is sure: And now, I weare my heart
Not in mne owne breast, but thine.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: I haue but one life, it is some error
In your Grace, thus t'oblige me to the losse
Of more, in your deare seruice.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: I am not skil'd in words. But I affect
Thy fury. For thou art the bold Satyr,
That whips Foreste, and the wanton Count,
In thy tart Verse.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: My gracious Lord! I shall conceiue much griefe,
If my zeale mistake in accusation
Of those Men, which th'vncertaine Tongue of Fame
Deliuers to my charge.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Nay, make not thy confession an excuse
Rather then a story: For there needs none.
I hate Foreste, and the Count, and would
Deuise succinct ways to my reuenge.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: Heauen forbid: I'de rather farre disgrace
The skill of my subiect; call accusation
Slander: then that the busie multitude
Should note inconstancy in you,

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: This is a damn'd Hypocrite. Chamellons
Changes, are not so intricate to sense.
Castruchio! ease me with nimble apprehension.
I haue not leasure, to be modest now.
Speake; hast no acquaintance with any neere
Corsa's person; the Counts faire wife?

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: I humbly beg, your Grace would not mistake
The conditions of my duty.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: I beg of thee not to mistake the sense
Of my designes. My words import my heart,
And both, no danger vnto thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: I hope my skill in seruitude, will not
Prouoke my Prince to tempt my honor.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: What prolixe loue is this; Dost thou indent
With my acceptance, make choyce of seruices!

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: Your Grace will giue me leaue; since that I know
I not deserue to share in your high secrets,
To doubt my safety in knowing this.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Death! and horror! thy suspitions are too thinne.
Consider why I sent the Count to Lucca?
Vpon my life thou art secure: therefore
Reply vnto my former question.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: My gracious Lord, I haue some interest
In her woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: In Corsa's woman knowne to thee?

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: She is. Perhaps—

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Discharge thy tongue. May my eares blister
If they digest words to thy preiudice.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: Perhaps I knew her, beyond the modest straine.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: There's Gold. Castruchio, shew some pitty
On rebellious blood. Be my Harbenger,
Billet me this night where she doth lye
And thou art made for euer.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: Must it be this night?

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Strict opportunitie will haue it so.
Her Lord returnes with the next Sunne.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: I cannot say her selfe shall porter be
Vnto your entrance; but her woman shall.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Enough! here's more Gold. Smmon vp thy braine
Thy heart, thy soule, to meet in consulation,
And so contriue my peace, Farewell.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: I will instruct your Grace e're long: both when,
And how to make this armorous assault.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: My selfe and my Exchequer are thine owne.
There needs no Art to worke him into euill;
He is bad enough t'infect the Deuill.

SP.SPEAKER: DORIDO,
SP.L: Good! they haue left the Garden dore vn∣locked
I'le venture in to helpe discouery.
Castruchio is grac'd with rare imployment:
The Duke and he doe heere consume the Night.
These are houres for Ghosts, Adulterers
And Theeues. The slaue is Haggard. At Supper
Being full of gold: his vaine Appetite
Fed at Nero's rate; I was discarded
With a frowne: shaken like a Burre from's sleeue.
As if my closure heeretofore had bin
Impertinent. Ambition lessens all
Beneath it selfe to nothing: the higher
We doe stand: so much lesse those men appeare
Whom we behold below—Hearke! Kinde Fortune
Lend me thy Eares—

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: The night growes aged now. T'were fit the Duke
Would hasten his departure. In troth Wench,
Thy seruice to him exceeds requitall.
But what; she tooke it willingly!

SP.SPEAKER: Dua.
SP.L: No, but she did not.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: Pox 'o these modest Lies! I say she did,

SP.SPEAKER: Duar.
SP.L: In troth you doe abuse her then; I'm sure
Her shreeks did scare my heart vp to my lipps.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: Then thou couldst haue Kiss'd heartely.

SP.SPEAKER: Duar.
SP.L: I wonder, it wakened not the whole house.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: Ist possible! what meanes did the Duke vse
To stifle vp this noyse?

SP.SPEAKER: Dua.
SP.L: Nay, I know not. But since she was no more
Pliant; it doth repent me much, I'ere
Was instrument to his other actions.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: What, repent! I prethee sweete Duarte
Wrong not Diuinitie so much: waste not
A virtue, that would more profit others:
And to suppose that the Lady was rauish'd,
Is an heresie, which my Soule must nere
Be guilty of. Doe not I know Women
Are a kinde of soft waxe, that will receaue
Any impression?

SP.SPEAKER: Dua.
SP.L: And doe not I know: there is difference
In workemen as in wax. Hard wax (when cold)
Accepts of no impression. By coldnesse
I in ferre chastitie: for chastitie
Is colde,

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: But those workemen are harder farre
Then that hard waxe. And t'is hardest of all
To finde those workemen: vnlesse by Russia
Where the people freeze, till they spit snow. Come,
Kisse me Chuck. Agen, once more—

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: A precious Satyrist! This surly Dog,
Inueyes 'gainst lechery in others, 'cause
He would engrosse all Women to himselfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: Your greatest Thieues, are commonly begot
When Parents doe their leachery by stealth.
Men get Cowards, when frighted in the Act.
And by such vulgar consequence: t'is now
A proper time to beget a Pander.
One, that may hereafter doe other men
The same office: which we doe the Duke now.
Come. Shall we, in and try?

SP.SPEAKER: Dua.
SP.L: You presume much, on an easie nature;
And how extrauagant you are abroad;
I am not so vnkind to question.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: Faith Wench: I've some interest in euery Childe
That playsi'th' streete, The Dukes come down. Go, go,
Giue your Lady a Cawdle: and let me heare
How she likes her new Bedfellow. I'le meete
His Grace two houres hence: when he hath dismiss'd
Those thoughts, which still succeed vnlawfull lust.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: O damn'd villany: Is this th'imployment
That doth make ye proude? I will haunt ye still,
To strengthen my intelligence.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: O silly, weake euasion! being darke,
I creepe within my Cloke. T' is modesty
In sinne to practise euery disguise
To hide it from the World. But Creatures free from guilt
Affect the Sunne, and hate the darke; because
It hides their innocence. O traytour Lust.
That leades vs with encouragement to fight,
And when we haue discharg'd our Vaines for thee,
W'are besieg'd with thoughts, that more perplex vs
Then the former. For then we did complaine
Of strength; but now of weaknesse more.
Away, way. T'is time that I were gone:
The modest Morne doth blush i'th' East, as if
Asham'd to see so fowle a Rauisher.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorido.
SP.L: So swift of foote! I must ouertake ye.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: How now! the World is wide enough: wherefore
Dost thou iostle me?

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: Cry mercy Signior: the day's bleare Eie'd yet,
And my owne hast made me vnmannerly.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: Sigior Dorido is it you? Tis much
To see you appeare before the Sunne.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: Faith Signior; the Count being out o' Towne
I though Foreste would haue more leasure
To peruse my new Sute. He's early vp;
Which caus'd my vigilance.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: Why Signior vse a meanes more absolute;
It is true, Foreste does all: but how?
As th'instrument gouern'd i'th' workemans hand.
Instruct me with conueniency of time,
And I will worke the Duke in thy behalfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: Then Signior, you will oblige my prayers.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: At supper, when you departed from me,
You gaue demonstrations of discontent:
Who knowes, but whilst the soul's imploy'd within;
The body might neglect some outward forme,
Which curiosity preferrs to custome.
Custome to abuse. It was my businesse
Not disrespect of you, that did depriue
My complement of vanity. I shall
Reioyce when I can shew you kindenesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorid.
SP.L: I will be bold to thinke so.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: I'de haue thee build thy Mansion on a Rocke.
Fauorites are seru'd in with those Dishes
The Prince best loues. And meate we most affect
We soonest surfeit on. Instruct thy soule.
The Count is but a glorious trifle.
And to be factious without benefit—
Well, thinke vpon't. I know a way to get
The Dukes best Eare, without Foreste's helpe.
Farewell.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: The Profit of the day be yours. These tricks
Shall make me weare him in my Eies. The slaue
Doth vsher out his breath in state; as if
His honours had out growne his owne knowledge.
Yet but a tame Pande. The beautious Corsa
Is rauish'd by the Duke. O blacke horror.
Arise my soule, inspire my industry
With noble purpose. Something I'le doe
That shall proclaime my Spirit.

SP.SPEAKER: Corsa.
SP.L: Hence, hence, like Time; who swiftly flys away,
But euermore returnes. Goe cruell wench!
Thou hast betray'd thy Mistresse, euen to
Eternall losse. Th'Angels that liue aboue
Haue seene it all. They know thee well enough.
In the generall Session of the world;
It will not my adultery be call'd;
But a prodigious Rape deriu'd from thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Duarte.
SP.L: Good Madam, your Conscience is too bold:
It troubles you too much. Dismise't: thinke,
That other Ladys haue offended more.

SP.SPEAKER: Corsa.
SP.L: Out Deuill. Wilt thou betray my soule too?
Duarte hence! I am inspired with strength
To make reuenge prooue masculine.
Flye quickely hence. Why doest thou stay? There's Gold.
I prethee wench in all thy Pilgrimage
Disperse my faulte in charitable sence.
Vse me nobly with thy Tongue. So farewell.

SP.SPEAKER: Duarte.
SP.L: Or let my sinne no mercy finde in Heauen,
No pitty heere on Earth.

SP.SPEAKER: Corsa.
SP.L: Now all the motiues of my Lords delight
Exterminate for euermore with me.
My silent Lute's interred in the Case.
My voyce now rather frights, then captiuates
The sence.
O Sister, dare you visit me?
I am a strumpet growne. Hence, and secure
Your fame.

SP.SPEAKER: Luin.
SP.L: Alack, what prodegie is this!

SP.SPEAKER: Corsa.
SP.L: I will tell thee all. For I should disgrace
Iniquitie to be modest now. The Duke—

SP.SPEAKER: Luin.
SP.L: Ay me! What in that name can priuiledge
Offence?

SP.SPEAKER: Corsa.
SP.L: Heare my Luinna, heare. In midst of night,
By my pernicious womans helpe; He opes
My chamber doore: whose faithfull Hinges shreek'd,
To warne me of his dire approach. His Hand
Imployd a Torch, a Torch; whose fancy weake
Aged, and blacke, had ouergrowen the flame.
And shew'd (me thought) like vnto Tarquins Ghost;
Preaching in fire: as if it counsell'd him,
To preuent such pennance by forsaking
His attempt. This, I told him too. But he
(That came not to consider, but to act)
O'reu'd my Hands with his: then made shipwrack
Of my Honor.

SP.SPEAKER: Luin.
SP.L: O royall Villaine!
My ioynts and sinnews dissipated are,
And scatter'd in a trembling feare. But marke
More sorrowes yet. My Husband lookeing in
My Cabinet, did spy that Iewell there,
Which the Duke last gaue me. It was to him
A new, and vnknowne starre: and Commet like,
Imployd his thoughts with such Astrologie
As made an Optick of his iealousie;
Through which, he would discerne the cause, th' effect
Of its being there. I told him all the truth:
And Truth's oftner praysed, then rewarded
Heere on Earth: for he dismiss'd me streight
With fatall lookes.

SP.SPEAKER: Corsa.
SP.L: My Brother is a noble Gentleman.
Goe, goe, and kneele to him. All iealousie
Must still be strangled in its birth: or Time
Will soone conspire to make it strong enough
To ouercome the truth. Shield vs sweete Heauen!
The Sybills daunce about my Heart. They lay
Their verges heere: infusing a prophetique feare:
Which whispers we shall neuer meete againe,
Lets take a solemne leaue—farewell for euer

SP.SPEAKER: Luin.
SP.L: Farewell! the noblest Lady o'th' World.

SP.SPEAKER: Cos.
SP.L: I am glad to see thee well Borachio!
But where's thy Master? what, in durance still?

SP.SPEAKER: Bora
SP.L: Alas Sir, I (Good Gentleman,) the Roome
Wherein they haue put him, is so litle
Hee fills it vp to the Roofe: and is faine
To leaue his Legges Sentinels without doore,
To watch the rest of his body. Tis no
Chamber, but a Court. Cubbord.

SP.SPEAKER: Cos.
SP.L: But they make him amends in his diet.

SP.SPEAKER: Bora.
SP.L: They cannot Sir, For he's a fainte eater,
If he would pray so often as he fasts;
He had bin at libertie long agoe.
He'le dine vpon a single Pea; and leaue Orts.

SP.SPEAKER: Cos.
SP.L: Doe they no more regard his potent hopes?

SP.SPEAKER: Bora.
SP.L: Alas Sir, when Fortune's Tippet stands vp,
Few men will lend a pin to tacke it downe,
I, and my linage haue sweete losse of him:
I'm sure o'that,

SP.SPEAKER: Cos.
SP.L: Nay, that's too euident.

SP.SPEAKER: Bora.
SP.L: O sir! I would not a'giuen this Rush;
T'haue bin assur'd all th'offices in's gift
But hang such Dukes (I say) that suffer thus
Their Fauorites to be imprisoned.

SP.SPEAKER: Cos.
SP.L: How now Borachio! Dost thou speake treason?

SP.SPEAKER: Bora.
SP.L: Sir, I haue sayd no more, then what I meane
To vnsay againe: which is but a kinde
Of loosing one' labor. An 'is better,
To be ill imploy'd then to be idle.

SP.SPEAKER: Cos.
SP.L: How the slaue sowes his Prouerbs together.
Are you come? I haue stay'd vntill the Clocke
Gaue your promise the lye.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: My time was spent to more aduantage.
I haue declar'd my interest in your blood.
If you assist my plots; you needs must share
Successe, that hath already warranted
A large requitall.

SP.SPEAKER: Cos.
SP.L: I am resolu'd: and wish my selfe more able.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: T'is well. But now you vndertake businesse:
You must be as serious as a Musle.
That is: weare your Beard, vpon your tongue: talke,
Brauely. But of all auoyd Dorido
As you would to drinke
A violent poyson.

SP.SPEAKER: Cos.
SP.L: Enough, he is a stranger to my thoughts.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: There's fresh encouragement—

SP.SPEAKER: Cos.
SP.L: A little more of this mettall would puzle
My Geography; Is this Italy
Or the Indies, There Borachio! Weepe no more
For thy Master.

SP.SPEAKER: Bora.
SP.L: Allas I'm apt to weepe, though I but see
An Onyon stripp'd naked.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: I thought to meete thy Master heere. I'm sure
I saw the warrant sign'd for his release.

SP.SPEAKER: Bora.
SP.L: The Deuill take your worship for me, why,
D'yee bring such good newes, on a work'y day?

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: But thou pray'st ill, in praying the Deuill
To take me.

SP.SPEAKER: Bora.
SP.L: Why could he euer come to lesse purpose
Then when he findes you doing well. Though he
Loose his labour once: I dare warrant ye,
He'le come againe on the same arrand.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: A bitter foole.

SP.SPEAKER: Bora.
SP.L: Sir, let we friends be true to one another.
There are but few true friends extant. Let them
Be kindly vs'd and kept, if only for breed.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: With all my heart, translate thy meaning.

SP.SPEAKER: Bora.
SP.L: Is my Master at liberty?

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: I'le deferre an answere of this, vntill
Thy owne Eies be a little elder.

SP.SPEAKER: Bora.
SP.L: Well, is he still in fauour with the Duke?

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: Why he shall shortly gouerne all at Court,
And be a very Mote in the Duk's eye.

SP.SPEAKER: Bora.
SP.L: Enough. T'is not wholesome to burst with oy.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: But what then?

SP.SPEAKER: Bora.
SP.L: I'ue thought with much care on these Offices:
And finde my selfe fitting to be in'em.
I will haue'em all; come Cut, and Long-taile.
For my Wife, will be such a glad woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Cos.
SP.L: Looke! who comes there?

SP.SPEAKER: Bora.
SP.L: O Sir! giue me your blessing—

SP.SPEAKER: Loth.
SP.L: Weepe not Borachio! I haue prepard
Such bloody art in my reuenge; as makes
Mens wits, more famous then their cruelty,
Let horror propagate. All's too litle
For my vse. But you Sir had the honor,
To release me.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: Or else I had bin much dishonor'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Cos.
SP.L: Sir, now he supposeth you in durance:
And is himselfe secure; happely drunke,
Or riding in the stewes; you may take some
Aduantage on his soule too. Loose no time.

SP.SPEAKER: Loth.
SP.L: That's my intent.
For it were dull humanitie to aime
No farther then his life. I'le pursue him
Euen to Hell.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: And let me alone so to facilitate
The proiect, by search of fit time, and meanes:
As shall declare the act lesse troublesome,
Then thus to threaten it with words.

SP.SPEAKER: Bora.
SP.L: You Signior Castrucho! Signior Coxcombe!
