Are you ti'd with doing well? you haue scarce
Brought my poore Lord out of the Prison doores;
But you long to haue him in agen. Nay,
N'ere looke! For my Sword dwells within a Yard
Of my Tongue, and shall defend what I say

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: What a prnicious Calfe is this?

SP.SPEAKER: Bora.
SP.L: What harme haue my poore Wife, and Children done
To you, or yours; that seeing me within
A haires breadth, of a hundred offices,
You confound all, by leading my poore Lord
Into new broyles.

SP.SPEAKER: Loth.
SP.L: Bold Miscreant! If I but stir—

SP.SPEAKER: Cos.
SP.L: Nay Signior! let him alone. Borachio!
Steepe thy wrath in cold water: follow,
And be dumbe. All shall be well.

SP.SPEAKER: Bora.
SP.L: Yes, perswade me to dry Ice in an Ouen!
But I'le follow your Heeles so close: as Ile
Goe neere to tread vpon your Kibes.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorido.
SP.L: Signior, I knew ye a braue Commander
Vnder the great Petruchio; and since
That time your constant virtues haue deseru'd
More recompence, then Fate will minister
By me. My kindenesse is no miracle:
Since gratitude is only sicke, not dead.
But pray beleeue what I haue sayd is truth.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: O Sir, t'is th'error of vnskilfull loue
To be too constant in her charitie
To all. But I haue grounds more relatiue
To make me iealouse of the truth: and I
Beleeue you with my heart: and yet t'is strange.
Doth this Castruchio thinke his haggard fate
Can triumph ouer mine? because in lust
The Deuill did instruct his industry:
Dares he attempt my life?

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: I giue you reall grounds for my suspence.
Reward (sir) may make a Villaine bloody
Though it cannot make him valiant. The Duke
Will let him want no Gold.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: Nay t'is often seene.
Amongst the seuerall Creatures of a Prince,
Such instruments as these most profit reape.
Imployments noble doe requite themselues,
And honour payes, the great of heart: who loose
But Time in seruice which is the Bodies wealth.
Your friend stays. If you please t'appeare with him
From thence, at my summons: I shall discouer more.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: Noble Signior, I am yours,

SP.SPEAKER: Forest.
SP.L: What hoa? Luinna! Wife!

SP.SPEAKER: Luin.
SP.L: My Lord!

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: Come hither Loue. Signefie in secret
When was the royall Lecher heere disguis'd?
What did he send thee last? when must ye quench
The Cyprian fire: hah! you may tell me all,
For I'le not blabb. Alas, I'm more silent
Then my Grandsire in his Tombe. A subtill Pimpe, I,
A Pander learned in the art. Tell me Chucke?

SP.SPEAKER: Luin.
SP.L: Alas my noble Lord! what doe ye meane?

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: Why nothing, I: yet tis enough I feele
The wrong, If ignorant, I suffer twice.
And therefore let me know my Enemy.
The little worme, when trod vpon; will turne
His Head, to looke vpon his Murderer.
And hath my Spleene no Eies: Is the reuenge
Of Man lesse curious then a Wormes.—She weepes,
O Luinna, the sacred knot's vnti'd.
Thou hast defil'd and stayn'd the vestall Sheetes,
Thy Breast shall be no more my Pillow.

SP.SPEAKER: Luin.
SP.L: O say not so. Let Thunder strike me dead,
If I'ere knew the 'Duke; with knowledge more
Dishonest, then what harbours in the Eies;
Only by sight.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: O new horror! such brazen impudence,
Would make a Negro blush. Come gloious whoe,
Acquaint me with your tricks. Who! when, where, how
For besides the Iewell which he gaue thee:
I haue proofes, that will euen damme my sister;
And conuince thee too.

SP.SPEAKER: Luin.
SP.L: My deere Lord? be not cruell in your Faith;
What I haue sayd is truth.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: Still constant in thy periurie. Mercy
Were tamensle then. Thou shalt dye
Like an heroyique Whore: a Martyr
SP.STAGE: Enter Doride and his Friend in visards.
SP.L: To thy concealed louer. Appeare ho!
Heere my she goate! These men are full and fresh;
But if they cannot tire ye out: I will
Procure ye some of larger Thighs; that feede
On th' vnctious Lhasis, and the Persian-Crab.
Or bring the riotous Horse, and the Towne Bull
To drownd ye in the act. Take her aside,
And agree who shall beginne.

SP.SPEAKER: Luin.
SP.L: Stay, stay, O my Husband, my deerest Lord?
Will you permit such cruelty against
Your owne Wife. She, that hath so often slept
Within your Bosome. O speake? doe you want
The naturall touch stay, stay, I will confes't.

SP.SPEAKER: Forest.
SP.L: Stay, I'm of too easie, too soft a Soule.
My Heartstrings (sure) are made of silke: and 'tis
A subtill whore, she knowes it well enough.
But come, be briefe. Charme me not with storys
Of my former loue betweene vs.
I see thee as thou art, and thou appear'st
Like an intire, proportionable Boyle.
Why speak'st thou not?

SP.SPEAKER: Luin.
SP.L: Sorrow was euer slow of vterance,
And I doe tremble still. I knew the time,
My duty hath bin held in more regard
Then now it is. All former interest
Is quit forgot.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: Marke, did not I suspect, she would begin
Her Charmes agen. Away with her.

SP.SPEAKER: Luin.
SP.L: O stay, now, now, I will reueale all.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: Be nimble then: and tell me punctuall truth,
For my reuenge is honest, and would not
Willingly mistake, when it shall strike.

SP.SPEAKER: Luin.
SP.L: T'is true, your Sster's rauish'd by the Duke.
Which fatall truth, this morning I receau'd
From her owne mouth, But if I ere did breake
My Mariage vowes, or thinke vnlawfully;
Then may I loose my interest in Heauen.
My duty, and my loue remaine still yours,
And this constancy deserues some kindnesse.
Therefore, if t'is decreed that I must dye:
Let me dye a modest death. Expose not
Your poore vvife, vnto the cruelty
Of Rauishers.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: What thinke ye sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: My thoughts continue in the former sence:
I haue a chaste, and virtuous vvife; howeuer
You desir'd assurance from a triall
So vnkind as this.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: Still me thinks that Iewell which he gaue her,
Procur'd the same requitall that my Sister made.
But let it passe. I doe coniure ye both,
(As y'haue bin Souldiers) to keepe your Tongues,
A safe distance from your Eares, Let not words
Disperse what you haue heard. T'is externall
Reputation that keepes some Men from sinne.
Our faults once knowne, we doe neglect to mend:
Since Reputation suffers still: for that
Admits of helpe, but it is neuer cur'd.
And so the fatall iarrs tweene Man, and Wife,
If secret kept, dissension falls asleepe.
But if once knowne to Fame; Fame talks so loude
She waketh it agen. Your silence Signiors,
Shall challenge much from my requitall.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: Besides our obligations to your worth,
Euen both our honors would impose it
As a virtue, not a trouble. We are
Your humble seruants.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: I will deserue you for my friends. Rise—
You must be cleer'd by a stricter triall:
'Till when I doe neglect the large Charter
Of Husbands o're their Wiues: and command ye
As a Iudge th'offendor. Hence, and become
My Prisoner in your Closet. Take heede,
No curiosity in feare make you,
To pry in my designes.

SP.SPEAKER: Luin.
SP.L: I doe obay ye cheerefully.

SP.SPEAKER: Forest.
SP.L: O my heart! shall my industry, and hopes
Finde this period? My sufferance is tir'd.
It is an old inconstancy in Fate,
Soone to erect, and soone to ruinate.

DIV2.HEAD: A Chayre at the Arras. Actus Quintus. Scena Prima.
DIV2.L: FORESTE, No, no, my Starres, it is too much to beare,
Though I were stomach'd like an Estridge,
Yet could I not digest such hard dealing.
My Wife defil'd, Corsa rauish'd. The Count
Abus'd where satisfaction is exempt
By Nature. My selfe proscrib'd to suffer
By the cheape vallour of obscure Villaines.
Would I had trode the humble path, and made
My industry lesse ambitious. The Shrub
Sccurelie growes. The tallest Tree, stands
Most in the winde. And thus we distinguish
The Noble from the base: the Noble finde
Their liues, and deaths still trouble some:
But humility doth sleepe, whilst the storme
Growes horce with scolding My Gall o'reflowes my heart:
And drownes propitious Thoughts. I will be iust
Yet cruell too. The darkenesse of the Night
Is thicke. I feele as I grope for way—
Stay—That sickly light from her chamber breaks.
Minion le beginne with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Corsa.
SP.L: Sing gentle youth; who knowes if I shall liue
Timploy thy voyce agen.

DIV3.HEAD: Song.
DIV3.L: Boy. Weepe no more for what is past
For Time in motion makes such hast
He hath no leasure to discry
Those errors which he passeth by.
It pays desert with bad euent:

SP.SPEAKER: Forest.
SP.L: This is your Dirge,

SP.SPEAKER: Corsa.
SP.L: Hah! who is there?

SP.SPEAKER: Fores
SP.L: Tis. I. Dismisse that trisle hence, and shut
The doore.

SP.SPEAKER: Corsa.
SP.L: Farewell Youth! Get hee to bed.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: But where's the rigled Hagg; th' incestuous lump
Of heate? where is she, speake?

SP.SPEAKER: Corsa.
SP.L: Alas Sir, who doe you meane?

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: Why she that Gossips with the Deuils Damme,
The subtill Bawde, your Woman. O Sister! Corsa kneeles.
I haue heard all.—Nay doe not worke distinction thus.
Kneele not to me; you are my Patrons wife.
But yet where obligation is indeer'd;
There Iniurie condemns it selfe. Can you
Suruie a wrong so eminent: a wrong
Committed' gainst your Husband, and my Patron?

SP.SPEAKER: Corsa.
SP.L: O Sir! I hope if you haue heard the trueth:
You will conclude it as a rape i'th' Duke;
And no adultery in me.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: How, a rape! o weake, and immodest shift,
Were Aretine aliue; or had I brought
A Crew of Midwiues heere: whose obscene art
Might warrant the distinction good;
Although the cause did blush, to owne th'effect;
Yet thy appeale might stand: but heere are none.
If compulsion doth insist, vntill
Enforcement breed delight, we cannot say,
The femall suffers. Acceptance at the last,
Disparageth the not consenting at the first:
Calls her dniall, her vnskilfulnesse;
And not a virtuous frost i'th' blood.
Come, sit thee downe.—Or if ye meane to pray,
Kneele, and be nimble in deuotion.
That art to dye.

SP.SPEAKER: Corsa.
SP.L: My Noble Brother!
Doe not fright my sufferance: vse me kindly
With your tongue, and lookes: I am already
Reconcil'd to Heauen; and would perhaps
Consent to your designe.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: Blessed speech! thou shalt prescribe my gesture
And my Phrase.

SP.SPEAKER: Corsa.
SP.L: T'were not vnnaturall in me, to wish
For life yet minding what constructions
The world may make of my sinister chance—

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: I there's the point. The giddy multitude
Haue neither skill, nor leasure to cnuince
Supposition, with Arguments of strength
And charitie. Their quicke censure, brings such
Effct, as Spectacles, when vs'd in hast;
Which then oe rather aggrauate the shape:
Then giu distinction of the forme. Who, who,
Would liue to be an Argument for them?

SP.SPEAKER: Corsa.
SP.L: Doe ye conclude then, that I must now dye?

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: Why ist not apt, and pregnant to your sence,
It should be so?

SP.SPEAKER: Corsa.
SP.L: Ere I take my last leaue of my kinde Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: Ceremonious forme, doth oft, so long
Delay our iourney; till it prooue too late
To reach our home. T'is a long way to Heauen.
We must make hast. Nay, if your courage faile
Before it comes vnto the test: I shall
Prepare to be vnkind. Grimme, black fancy
Could you indure to see your Lord; defil'd,
Polluted as you are? That kinde Patron
To all our family; whose constant loue
Is warranted by Time; that best can iudge
Of constancy. Who tooke you to his bed;
Vpon conditions cheape, and dangerous
To his owne estate.

SP.SPEAKER: Corsa.
SP.L: Sir, speake no more: but vse me as you please;
I will obay in all.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: Come, stretch downe your Arme: and permit this Scarfe
To fastne it to th' Chaire. Then vaile your Eies.
We must not trust a Woman's vallour so—

SP.SPEAKER: Corsa.
SP.L: Oh, oh, oh.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores,
SP.L: The torture's past. Thy wrist waynes are cut, Heere
In this Bason bleed: till drynesse make them curle
Like Lute-strings in the fire—

SP.SPEAKER: Corsa.
SP.L: Commend me to my deerest Lord. I am
His humble sacrifice. Hee'le not be more
Vnwilling to grant attonement: then I
Haue beene to neede it. The Fates giue others
Expiation: which now they want themselues.
I speake too loude. For who dares chide with them
That may imploy Thunder.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: Her beauty'gins to wither. She distills
Like to a Rose. O could I separate
The blood defil'd from what is pure: I would
Shed that; then restraine the current, know!
(Vnskilfull Nature) If operation
Should long subsist in such grosse mixture: Men,
Would be Deuils 'ere they liu'd in Hell.

SP.SPEAKER: Corsa.
SP.L: I come Celestiall Quire!—

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: Extasie! through weakenes in expence of blood!
Deare sister! Disturbe not your last Minutes.

SP.SPEAKER: Corsa.
SP.L: I must ascend—

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: How! would you enter Heauen; with fetters on
Your Soule? clogg'd with these mortall Limbs. Sit downe,
Expire in peace.

SP.SPEAKER: Corsa.
SP.L: O my Brother! whilst I am yet humane,
Let me feele some interest in your blood.
What fault of mine deserues impediments
In my last iourney? If my Lord were heere
He would haue seene me vs'd with mercy.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: Sweete Soule! these, are but mistakes of weake' nesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Corsa.
SP.L: Will not my Lord be mercifull; to me,
And to my memory.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: Sit still. I bring no negatiue reply.
Thy worth shall shine in such a Character:
That being dead; he needs must wooe thy Ghost.

SP.SPEAKER: Corsa.
SP.L: And will Posterity consent, that I
Abide in List; with those of modest fame?

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: That Astrologer; who spys thee first
Within a Starre: must not finde thee billeted
Neere to Venus. Such error in his Act;
Would make me wreath his Body into Cords.
And with prolix strength draw the dull Caytiffe,
Through his slender Optick.

SP.SPEAKER: Corsa.
SP.L: Oh, oh, oh—

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: A Convulsion in her Arteries!

SP.SPEAKER: Corsa.
SP.L: Mercy Heauen!

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: Hearke!
As she ascends, the Spheares doe welcome her,
With their owne Musicke.—Her Soule is gone!
Hah? whether is it gone? O vast suspence!
Madnesse succeeds inquirie. Fooles of Nature!
What Ancestor (that dyde long since) hath brought
Vs newes of his abode! or told vs how
They vse him in the other world? O this
Wilde mysterie so much concerneth Man:
That we would willingly dismisse suspence
With Eiesight not with consequence.
For he that sees through Faith, but flatters doubt.
Faith's a Perspectiue; through whose narrow lane;
Little things (far of) seeme so much too great,
Too neere: that what was first vnknowne is more
Estrang'd from knowledge, then it was before.
Yet by the rules of lawfull notion: It
Goes well with her: for she was euer giuen
To prayer: superstitious in humilitie:
And euen vnthrifty in her charitie.
She held her Virtues in such high extreames,
That her Diuinity was troublesome.
Grew from a Saint, a holy Cynick. Sleepe heere:
A sacriice to thy wrong'd Lord: Till I
(Thy Pries't) become an Executioner
To him; who was thy cruell Rauisher.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Doth she insist in censure of the act
With such a sterne impatience, and dislike?

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: Euen so (Sir) my intelligence imports.
For since her Woman, was dismissed: she sent
A Messenger vnto Lucca; to vrge,
Her Lords returne: whom (by a labor'd consequence)
I doe expect within this Hower. Hee'le choose
To trauaile in the Night for priuacie.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: And I haue sent to stay him there: vntill
A new Commission order his returne.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: Most royall Sir, you then may guesse what frights
Such opposition in these messages
Will nourish in his Heart. And being yong,
He cannot feede on doubts. Hee'le rather thinke
His interest in you his preuiledge to erre:
So, slight your Mandate, and come home,
To settle his suspence.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke
SP.L: Remorse doth cherish danger! Let me be safe,
Secre me in thy wholesome Art. I would
Expresse my selfe without a Tongue—

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: My gracious Lord; my apprehension lies
Not in my Eares but in my Braine. I can
Conceiue without the noyse of words. It shewes
Apparent to my intellect: the Count
Presuming on that free adresse, he still
Hath had vnto your person: will hither bring Corsa, and Foreste to shew the shape,
And quallity, of his new sufferance.
Be you within your bed, to free you from
The worlds suspition: whilst I doe place
Behind the Gallery doore (which leads vnto
Your Closset Chappell) such trusty spirits,
As shall dare to thrust their weapons home.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: O quintesence of Soule. I will deuote
My actions wholly to thy vse. Good night.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: May slumber ceaze vpon your toyall Eies
With gentle closure. Know, poore Foreste!
The bag that holds my Gall is so immense,
That when I steepe thee in it thou art drownd.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Castruchio; I haue better thought vpon't.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast
SP.L: My gracious Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: I would not haue thee hurt my Boy: vse him
Kindly for my sake.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: Shall I not strike him heere; betweene the Ribbes?

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Not for the world. Thou dost not know his Soule.
He's of so soft, so sweete a propertie,
That he inchants where he is knowne. Besides,
I finde I am so powerfull o're his youth:
That I shall soone extirpate from his memory
The wrong I did his Wife, and him. As for
Foreste: his experience is of growth
Too stubborne, of practise stiffe; and will not
Be remoo'd from his reuenge, by strength of words.
Therefore, let him no mercy feele: but let;
My Boy be gently vs'd for my sake. Farewell—

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: This is a silly kinde of loue!
But let me thinke—So to contriue this plot:
That Lothario may destroy Foreste,
And him to make his silence safe! humh—

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: No; it must not be—

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: My royall Lord!

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Lucio (my Boy) is not proscrib'd. Take heed
Castruchio! If thou dost extend thy hand:
In motion, boysterous, and rough to him;
Thou dost infect all thy other kindnesse:
And I shall see thee as a Cocatrice:
That will enforce my Optick-nerues to shrinke,
And pull my Eies into my skull. Looke to't.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: Most gracious Sir, were his person bulwark'd
With the Alpes: were he hidden ins owne feare;
He could not be more safe, then you haue made him.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Once more then good Night.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: A plague vpon this turdy loue. Such thoughts
When first your Blood did make your Vaines to swell
(Like Bridges'ore your flesh) had preuented
My imployment. Softely, softely.
Feare, and suspition euer walke on Egges.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Foreste, and Seruants with a Light.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: Leaue heere the Light, and goe to Bed.
Breake ope the doore, breake ope the doore.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: Hah! who counsels so vnlawfully?

SP.SPEAKER: Lucio.
SP.L: O Foreste! the fatall Houre is come
Ring out your Bells, vntill they wake the dead.
Let the Drumme murmure in a able Bagge.
Reuerse your Muskets, and traile your stubborne Pikes
In slimy-Channels. Let Trumpets groane,
And the shrill Phiph be hoarce. The fatall Hower,
Is come.

SP.SPEAKER: Forest.
SP.L: Why, what's the matter Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Lucio.
SP.L: O my wife! by this she did entreat me
Suddenly, (vpon some vrgent cause)
To haste from Lucca to her: Iust now;
I lighted from my Horse, enter'd her Chamber:
And found her newly murdered in her Chayre.
My Seruants say that my arriuall there,
Did iust succeed your departure from her.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: Dismisse your Seruants, and you shall know all.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucio.
SP.L: Hence, and expect me strait at home.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: I pray come hither Sir.—Doe you dislike

DIV3.L: That iustice which depriu'd your Wife of breath?

SP.SPEAKER: Lucio
SP.L: Doest thou call it Iustice?

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: Yes, in the noblest straine: she was defil'd.
The royall Goate (the Duke) hath rauish'd her:
And I (that neuer could admit excuse
In points of honor) (where euer suspition
Sufficeth to condemne) did summon vp
My memory: wherein the kinde effects,
Of your best loue to vs are registred.
And finding you betray'd in your owne Fort!
I slit her Wrist-aynes, and gaue perpetuall
Liberty, to her polluted Blood.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucio.
SP.L: O Villaine! more bloody then the Tyger;
Whose empty Entrailes noyse, doth (Trumpet like)
Encourage cruelty; Though thou didst flight her
As my poore Wife: yet she might well expect
Some mercy, as being thy owne sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: Had she included all propinquity
Of blood; which lawfull Mariage keepeth knowne,
Or promiscuous Copulation, maketh
Intricate: this bare word (Honor) had bin
Enough, t'haue diuorc'd her from my mercy.
Sweete Lord; doe not mistake your Seruant:
Whose kindenesse thinks his owne Sister (when defil'd)
Was to base for your vse.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucio.
SP.L: A bloody kindnesse to distinguish so
She was no Adulteresse, but enforc'd. Her thoughts
Were pure: and such a noble sympathy
Indeerd her Soule to mine; that her owne Teares,
Might soone haue wash'd away her Bodys staine,
And she againe seeme cleane. Corsa!
O my Wife! my bosome Girle! where art thou?
Speake, no reply? Art thou so much busied
With thy new acquaintance now in Heauen:
That thy poore Lord, may not borrow one word
At parting? Draw, draw ingratefull Monster!
That hast preuented thus our Dialogue.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: Sir, coole your spleene! take breath awhile:
And heare me speake.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucio.
SP.L: No false Syren! thou holy Hypocrite!
I know thy tricks too well! 'Cause I am yong,
Too soft of heart, and apt to melt
In euery flame of my owne triuiall loue;
Therefore thou thinkst to practise on me now
With subtill phrase. Draw, or else thou dy'st.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: Come—Let me dye (as she) a sacrifice
To thee my Patron.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucio.
SP.L: A sacrifice to me! O Foreste!
Why dost thou multiply thy skill
To thy friends priudice? It is not well,
In troth it is not. Imploy thy owne heart:
Thinke vpon't thy selfe. Tis not kindely done:
I should not haue vs'd you thus—

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: O my deere Lord! where did I loose your heart?
I am o'recome at these expressions.
I cannot weepe much: yet my Eies are moyst.
O my vnskilfull gratitude! what dire
Mistake, confounds our properties! I kill'd
A Sister, to secure a Friend. T'was ill,
Twas not the right way. A true Romane now,
Would walke aside, and with his owne Sword
Dismisse his owne Soule: and not permit
Moysture in youthfull Eies, thus to disgrace
The strength of elder loue. I cannot weepe,
But our diuinity supplyes vs with
Discreeter wayes, to make affection knowne;
Enough. I will prefix but one short Houre,
To thinke vpon't. Heere sir. Sheath your good sword,
Till reuenge prooue ripe. And I coniure
By all my Sisters loue to follow me:
In whose behalfe, your instice may imploy
It selfe. Which done, you shall behold my Heart
Without a Perspectiue.
If it concerneth her; by whom thou dost
Coniure my seruice, I'm bound to follow thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: What hoa!

SP.SPEAKER: Luin.
SP.L: My Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: Come Minion, come along with vs. You walke
Vnto the Barte. If triall find thee false;
Thou shalt be scattered into Attomes▪

SP.SPEAKER: Luin.
SP.L: O my deuining Soule▪ Sure my Sister
Is not safe.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Castruchio, Lothario, Cossimo, seuerall wayes.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: Signior Lothario!

SP.SPEAKER: Loth.
SP.L: Heere! Signior Cossimo!

SP.SPEAKER: Cos.
SP.L: I am heere. Speake low. Cosen Castruchio.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: I am heere too. Why are we scattered thus?

SP.SPEAKER: Cos.
SP.L: T'is in search of Borachio; who fearing
Danger in this action, commits himselfe
Very tamely to his Heeles.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: Let him be damn'd vnthought of. Haue you heard,
Or seene a Passenger.

SP.SPEAKER: Cos.
SP.L: No, yet Lothario giues me notice:
Of a noyse farre off: but you know the length
Of an Asses eare.

SP.SPEAKER: Loth.
SP.L: Pastes there (say you) who is't?

SP.SPEAKER: Cos.
SP.L: He ecchoes by mistake. No body: but
My Cousen says he'le lugge the Asses eare,
Speaking of your Man.

SP.SPEAKER: Loth.
SP.L: The Butchers dog shall saue him a labor.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: Well Gentlemen, I haue intelligence
(By my Boy) that Foreste, and the Count,
Are comming hither. Looke to't. But let the Count
Be safe. You know his voyce Lothario?

SP.SPEAKER: Loth.
SP.L: Very distinctly.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: Well, any Man (but he) that stirres his Tongue,
Enuites his owne ruine Giue me your Hands
I'le bring ye to a doore: through which, if they
Doe passe, it must be ouer vs.

SP.SPEAKER: Loth.
SP.L: Leaue Foreste to my charge for I am
His impediment.

SP.SPEAKER: Cos.
SP.L: Softely, softely.

DIV3.STAGE: The Duke (on his Bed) is drawne forth. Enter Foreste, Lucio, Luinna.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: Now set the reflex at liberty:
Heere let me beg your tariance: 'till I
Resolue a doubt that most concernes my Heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucio.
SP.L: You shall. But doe not execute reuenge,
Vpon the Duke; till my assent encourage thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: My actions are confin'd: Vpon, not in
The Bed? Guilt confounds all order, and makes,
Our rest vnnaturall. Mistresse, stand you there.

DIV3.STAGE: He leads Her to stand at the Beas feete.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Hah! from whence that light! who waites within

SP.SPEAKER: Foreste,
SP.L: is it you? what doe you meane
By this vnciuill visitation!

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: I am not so vnthrifty of time
To ioyne replys, vnto demands, I must
Depriue you of your Soule.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: How? Is this Language lawfull, vnto me
Thy Soueraigne Prince. Did not high-prouidence,
Treble the assurance of my safety:
By Guards inuisible, when I was first
Predestinate to this supreame function?
And darst thou tempt the strength of Heauen?

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: I know t' were a prophane curiosity
In me, to question the prerogatiues
Of a free Prince. For Ignorance, and a dull,
Easie faith; must flatter bondage still.
Or Libertie (th'eldest Child of Nature)
Confounds predominance, by suing for
Equalitie amongst the Sonnes of Men:
And so reuokes a Chaos.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Which soone returnes: vnlesse distinction
Perswade thee fixe my Royalty, aboue
Thy reach: that art my naturall Subiect.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: Enough false Sir. Warme not the ayre with words.
Be still, or I conclude ye in a trice,
And now requite the Leasure, I permit
For prayer: by a true reply to what
I shall demand.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: I will.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: Looke on your opposite.
Did you euer make her an Adulteresse?
Speake truth, so come your Soule to Heauen.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Neuer. So come my Soule to Heauen, as I
Speake truth.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: O Sir?
Take heede the Periurer hath little hope
On the last day, to hide himselfe i'th' Crowde.
He is a sinner much too eminent.
But what meant that Iewell which you gaue her;
And which she conceald; till its owne lusture
Did betray it?

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: I gaue it to disguise the cause, for which
I sent the other vnto Corsa.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucio.
SP.L: That name will prick my fury on: although
I striue to be propitious.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: I know Luinna, thou art mercifull:
Forgiue me gentle Girle. It was the first
Bargaine we did make i'th' Church, to Share
In sufferance.

SP.SPEAKER: Luin.
SP.L: And 'tis my duty Sir, to be most prompt
In the obseruance.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores,
SP.L: My Lord!

SP.SPEAKER: Lucio.
SP.L: A rude summons, that calls me as a Iudge,
To censure on the errors of my Prince.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: What, Is he there too? O killing obiect!

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: Behold (yong Lord) the cruell Rauisher.
Whom Time himselfe shall neuer parallell,
Though he suruay his old Records, and scratch
His reuerend Head to waken memory.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucio
SP.L: O horror! furnish vs (sweet Heauen) with some
Instinct. Inspire remorse: or we accuse
Thy skilfulnesse to predestine vs a Prince:
Murdring, whom thou didst annoint our Soueraigne.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: My heart swells. I'm full of griefe, and danger.
Some Iron Hoopes to helpe my Ribbes, or I shall burst.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: The cause deserues great alteration.
More then mortallity can see, and yet
Be safe. I wonder Heauen takes so little
Notice of it. I am not sindg'd to death
With Lightning Like the Dorr: nor murdred through
The Eare with thunder; like a Batt. O Lucio!
Minde not my former loue: but strike, vntill
I groane my last.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucio.
SP.L: Foreste sheath thy sword. It must not be.
He was our Royall Master once, and might
In modesty compare himselfe; with all
But Princes; whom Fame reserues as Paternes,
For my sake sheath your Sword.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: O I shall suruiue my Royall Charter!
My creature is more beautifull then I:
More wealthy in his loue.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: For my owne part, I will annihilate
My selfe: for should I liue, I should grow madde.
But I am bound to care for you (my Lord)
Take heede! I know the tricks of Maiestie.
They thinke they cannot be secure after
Doing ill; but by doing worse: that is,
By killing quite, whom erst they did but wound.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucio.
SP.L: And that's the surgery, which I desire.
I will endure all. O my Lord, my Lord;
I will not bid Posterity tell tales: nor charge
Historians to insert in Annalls;
On such a Night a great Italian. Duke,
Rauish'd his Creature Lucio's Wife: Sister
To Foreste, his actiue Councellor.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: Lucio, compos'd of such an humble loue:
That to secure his Masters feete, would spread.
And scatter all his Limmes, for him to walke vpon.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucio.
SP.L: And Foreste, whose industry, and care
Outwatch'd Leane-vigilance, 'till she grew mad.
But come, Let's leaue him to contriue our deaths.
My Heart so fills my mouth, I cannot speake.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Lucio stay, Foreste stay awhile.
Leaue me not thus anatomiz'd with breath.
Dissect me really with your good Swords.
Behold my Breast, take out my Heart: and if
You finde your figures there, then vse my Fame
With Mercy.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucio.
SP.L: Foreste come away.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: Make hast Luinna.

SP.SPEAKER: Luin.
SP.L: I am wak'd out of a strange amazement.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Hide me swelling Hills! rough, and scabbed Rocks,
Ye Quarrles cleaue, and sucke me in, then ioyne
Againe. Would it not make a Patriarke mad?
O who shall bribe the Sunne, that in the day
Of generall accompts: he may auouch
He neuer saw me heere. Hah! false Memory!
I forgot to tell 'em of Castruchio.
Tis best to o'retake 'em. I cannot guesse
Which way they went.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: Hell, and the Pillary take such dull Eares.
It cannot be, but they haue pass'd the Cloysters,
And e're this, with helpe of priuate Keyes,
Entred the Dukes Bedchamber.

SP.SPEAKER: Loth.
SP.L: Those were Authors of that noyse, I spoke of.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: The very same. A pox vpon demurres.

SP.SPEAKER: Cos.
SP.L: Will you lead the way, that we may hearken
If they be there, or no.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: If I should come too late?—

SP.SPEAKER: Loth.
SP.L: That's none of the Counts voyce. Haue at ye sir;

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: O, O, O, I am surpriz'd in my owne snare.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: It is Foreste sure. Let's make safe worke
Kill Lothario, lay him by him, and depart,

SP.SPEAKER: Cos.
SP.L: A match.

SP.SPEAKER: Loth.
SP.L: O Villaines, O, O, O.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: What noyse is that?

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: Another Foreste.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucio.
SP.L: My Royall Master bleeding on the Ground:
O murderous Villaines:

SP.SPEAKER: Luin.
SP.L: Murder, murder. Helpe! oh helpe?

DIV3.STAGE: Lucio fights with Cossimo, Foreste with Castruchio.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: The Duke my Soueraign slae, and Lucio
Bleeding at his feete. Villaine take this thrust
At my owne preiudice.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucio.
SP.L: I am foyld by a base hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: Flie Cosime, flie.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: Some comfort yet remaines: in that I am,
Proscrib'd to share in thy fate, though it be bad.
I loose much blood. O triuiall fortitude,
False Sinnewes, doe you begin to shrinke?

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Lucio, Let my Soule, cary your pardon
With her vnto Heauen; and yours Foreste.
This strangeme was mine, but the successe,
Was much against my will.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucio.
SP.L: Sir, I forgiue you all.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: Nay let vs ioyne Hands.—We doe forgiue
Each other, and the World. The like mercy
May Heauen bestow on vs.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Amen, Amen.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucio.
SP.L: Amen, Amen.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: There his heartstrings broke. Lucio (my Patron)
Already Chapflne to: that sight deserues a Teare:
Though I should stabb my Eies to warrant it.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Dorido, Luinna, Courtiers with Light: Castruchio: and Cosimo: led in.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: Bring the slaues in, their deeds will soone conuince
Their faint deniall, where did you leaue 'em Lady?

SP.SPEAKER: Luin.
SP.L: Here, here, O my Lord, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Fores.
SP.L: I haue not breath enough to comfort thee.
With words, mercy Heauen.

SP.SPEAKER: Luin.
SP.L: O my Lord? my Husband He's dead, he's dead.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: Hold the Lady there: O dire spectacle.
the Duke, Lucio, Foreste, and Lothario
Lye here breathlesse. I did suspect some blacke
Conspiracy. Which made me haunt them two
Vnto the Pallace, but I did loose 'em
By the Chappell staires; bloody dogs, what Deuill
Prompted thee to this action.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: I hope, I'ue not so much Blood left, as will preserue
Me for an answeere.

SP.SPEAKER: Cos.
SP.L: I feele my end to neere.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: Take em away, and close their wounds, though there
Be some mercy shewne, by thus deferring
That reward which your blacke soules shall receaue
In Hell. Yet know the Law will heere on Earth
Prouide such tortures as shall make your deaths
Exemplary to all succeeding times.—
SP.STAGE: exeunt some with Cast. and Cos.
SP.L: Gentlemen, your silence may be excus'd.
Where, theres so much cause of admiration.
Some helpe transfer the dead from hence, others
Call vp the Councellors of state.
So intricate is Heauens reuenge gainst lust.
The righteous suffer here, with the vniust.
